questions.text: Which of the following is marked in the given picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The image provided shows a dorsal view of an early vertebrate embryo stained to highlight developing neural structures. The neural fold is a key feature in the process of neurulation, where the neural plate folds to form the neural tube. The darkly stained, raised lateral edges on either side of the midline (as marked by the arrow) indicate the neural folds, which are moving towards each other to eventually fuse and form the neural tube. This structure is critical for the formation of the central nervous system, including the brain and spinal cord. The neural folds are visible as the elevated edges of the neural groove, which is the central depression along the embryonic midline.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tail of caudate nucleus

The tail of the caudate nucleus (Option A) is not found in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. The tail of the caudate nucleus is located more posteriorly and superiorly, forming a curve that extends into the temporal lobe but does not occupy the floor of the inferior horn. The structures that line the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle are related to the limbic system and hippocampal formation, which are critical for memory and emotional processing.

questions.text: Trigeminal nerve spinal nucleus second order neuron for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Out of the three sensory nuclei of the trigeminal nerve
❖ Chief sensory nucleus is mainly responsible for serue of touch,
❖ Spinal nucleus for sense of pain and temperature,
❖ Mesencephalic nucleua for sense of proprioception.

(The mesencephalic nucleus is unique in the sense that it is the only site in CNS which contains the cell bodies of first order sensory
neurons).

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is supplied by Lateral plantar nerve ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1st Interossei

The 1st interossei (Option B) is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve. The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve and innervates most of the intrinsic muscles of the foot, including the interossei muscles. The interossei are important for controlling the movement of the toes, particularly for adduction and abduction, and the 1st interosseus muscle is supplied specifically by the lateral plantar nerve.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A- 4, B- 1, C- 2, D- 3

a. Pectoralis major - 4. Flexion: The pectoralis major is primarily responsible for flexion of the shoulder joint, especially the clavicular part. It also helps with adduction and medial rotation of the arm, but flexion is its primary action.

b. L. dorsi - 1. Extension: The latissimus dorsi is a powerful muscle responsible for extension of the shoulder, along with adduction and medial rotation. It plays a key role in pulling movements like climbing.

c. Supraspinatus - 2. Abduction: The supraspinatus is part of the rotator cuff group of muscles and is mainly responsible for the first abduction of the arm (initiating the movement before the deltoid takes over).

d. Infraspinatus - 3. Lateral rotation: The infraspinatus is another rotator cuff muscle, and its main function is lateral rotation of the shoulder, helping in stabilizing the shoulder joint.

choices.text: Internal oblique and Trans Abdominis make roof

questions.text: Regarding Inguinal Canal which is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The inguinal canal is a passage in the lower anterior abdominal wall that transmits structures such as the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females. The canal has several walls and structures that contribute to its formation:

  • A. Trans Abdominis makes Anterior wall: This is incorrect. The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis and, in part, by the internal oblique muscle. The transversus abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall.

  • B. Internal oblique and Trans Abdominis make roof: This is correct. The roof of the inguinal canal is formed by the arch of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. These muscles form a muscular arch that covers the canal.

  • C. External oblique makes posterior wall: This is incorrect. The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is formed by the transversalis fascia and part of the conjoint tendon (formed by the fusion of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis).

  • D. Fascia Transversalis makes floor: This is incorrect. The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, which is a fold of the external oblique aponeurosis, not the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: Patient suffered from medial epicondyle fracture. Which nerve is injured in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The medial epicondyle is a bony prominence on the inner side of the humerus, and it serves as the attachment point for several muscles and ligaments. The ulnar nerve runs near the medial epicondyle, and it is especially vulnerable to injury in cases of fractures in this region.

questions.text: A. Patient presents with Nystagmus and vomiting. On examination, there is loss of pain and temperature of left side of face and right side of body. Also there is hoarseness of voice. Which artery is involved in this patient.?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The clinical features presented—nystagmus, vomiting, loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the face and the right side of the body, and hoarseness of voice—are indicative of a lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome is typically caused by occlusion or infarction of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

Here’s how the symptoms correlate with PICA involvement:

Nystagmus and vomiting: These symptoms are often associated with vestibular dysfunction or cerebellar involvement, which can occur when the PICA supplies the vestibular nuclei and parts of the cerebellum.

Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the face and right side of the body: This is characteristic of a crossed sensory loss (contralateral body, ipsilateral face), which occurs when the PICA affects the spinothalamic tract and trigeminal nerve nuclei in the medulla.

Hoarseness of voice: This suggests cranial nerve X (vagus nerve) involvement, which can occur when PICA infarcts the nucleus ambiguus, affecting motor control of the pharynx and larynx.

questions.text: Which muscle causes Flexion, lateral rotation and abduction at hip and Flexion in knee
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The muscle labeled A in the image is the Sartorius muscle. Sartorius is the longest muscle in the human body and plays a key role in several movements. It flexes, abducts, and laterally rotates the hip, and also flexes the knee. It originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and inserts onto the medial surface of the tibia via the pes anserinus. Because it crosses both the hip and knee joints, it contributes to movements at both joints. This action pattern — flexion at the hip, lateral rotation, abduction at the hip, and flexion at the knee — is characteristic of Sartorius and fits perfectly with the movement described in the question.

questions.text: Which of the following passes between superior & middle constrictor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The stylopharyngeus muscle is the only muscle that passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles. It originates from the styloid process of the temporal bone and travels inferiorly along with the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX). As it descends, it slips between the superior and middle constrictors to insert into the posterior pharyngeal wall. This anatomical relationship is clinically important, especially in surgeries involving the pharynx and in understanding pathways for nerve blocks. The stylopharyngeus functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speaking, contributing to the coordinated action of the pharyngeal muscles.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1. Pompe’s Disease → A. Glycogen accumulation in lysosome

•   Enzyme deficiency: Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase)

•   Pathophysiology: In Pompe disease, glycogen cannot be broken down inside lysosomes, leading to massive glycogen accumulation within lysosomes, especially in cardiac and skeletal muscle.

•   Clinical features: Cardiomegaly, hypotonia, muscle weakness, and early death (especially in infantile form).

2. Von Gierke’s Disease → B. Hepatomegaly and splenomegaly

•   Enzyme deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphatase

•   Pathophysiology: Liver cannot release glucose into the bloodstream → leads to hypoglycemia and glycogen accumulation in liver and kidneys.

•   Clinical features: Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia.

3. McArdle’s Disease → C. Exercise intolerance

•   Enzyme deficiency: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

•   Pathophysiology: Muscles can’t break down glycogen for energy during exercise → leads to exercise intolerance.

•   Clinical features: Muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (dark urine) after exercise, fatigue, and elevated creatine kinase (CK).

4. Cori’s Disease → D. Branched product accumulation

•   Enzyme deficiency: Debranching enzyme (alpha-1,6-glucosidase)

•   Pathophysiology: Incomplete breakdown of glycogen → abnormally structured glycogen with short outer branches.

•   Clinical features: Mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, muscle weakness. Less severe than Von Gierke’s due to preserved gluconeogenesis.

questions.text:
Korsakoff psychosis true except?

1. Amnesia

2. Confabulation

3. Ophthalmoplegia

4. Neuropathy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 3, 4

Korsakoff

psychosis is a late complication of persistent Wernicke encephalopathy and results in memory deficits, confusion, and behavioral changes. 

Korsakoff psychosis is not associated with Opthalmoplegia and neuropathy.

Wernicke Korsakoff syndrome
Results from vitamin B1 deficiency. Symptoms can be precipitated by administering dextrose before vitamin B1.

Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia (Wernicke encephalopathy).
May progress to irreversible memory loss, confabulation, personality change (Korsakoff syndrome).
Treatment: IV vitamin B1 (before dextrose).

questions.text: Glycogen Phosphorylase is activated directly or indirectly by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B12 deficiency is the most likely cause of lower limb weakness in a post-gastrectomy patient. After gastrectomy, the stomach’s ability to produce intrinsic factor—a glycoprotein essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the terminal ileum—is impaired. Over time, this leads to vitamin B12 deficiency. Neurological symptoms of B12 deficiency can include paresthesias, numbness, and progressive weakness, especially in the lower limbs, due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (affecting the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts). This can manifest as unsteady gait, spasticity, and weakness. Hematologic findings such as megaloblastic anemia may also be present, but neurological symptoms may precede or occur independently.

questions.text: A patient with cardiomyopathy and muscle weakness was diagnosed to have Barth syndrome. What is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Barth syndrome is a rare X-linked genetic disorder that primarily affects cardiac and skeletal muscle, often presenting with cardiomyopathy, muscle weakness, growth delay, and neutropenia. The underlying defect in Barth syndrome is in the remodeling of cardiolipin, a unique phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Cardiolipin is essential for optimal function of enzymes involved in oxidative phosphorylation and mitochondrial energy production. In Barth syndrome, mutations in the TAZ gene lead to abnormal cardiolipin composition, which disrupts mitochondrial structure and energy production, particularly in energy-demanding tissues like the heart and muscles. This explains the clinical presentation of cardiomyopathy and muscle weakness

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood, leading to premature atherosclerosis and increased risk of coronary artery disease. The most common cause of FH is a mutation in the gene coding for the LDL receptor (LDLR). This receptor is responsible for clearing low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles from the circulation by mediating their uptake into liver cells. A defect in the LDL receptor leads to reduced clearance of LDL, causing cholesterol to accumulate in the blood. Clinically, FH presents with xanthomas, corneal arcus, and early-onset cardiovascular disease, often before age 50.

choices.text: Alpha oxidation in mitochondria and ER

questions.text: Refsum disease is due to deficiency of which enzymes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Refsum disease is a rare inherited disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme involved in alpha-oxidation of phytanic acid in the peroxisomes. Phytanic acid is a type of branched-chain fatty acid that cannot be broken down properly without the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase, which is responsible for initiating alpha-oxidation.

•   In Refsum disease, the inability to perform alpha-oxidation leads to the accumulation of phytanic acid in various tissues, including the nervous system, retina, and heart, leading to a variety of symptoms, including neurological issues, retinitis pigmentosa, sensorineural hearing loss, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Why the other options are incorrect:

B. Alpha oxidation in mitochondria and ER:
•   The primary site of alpha-oxidation is in the peroxisomes, not in the mitochondria or endoplasmic reticulum (ER). This makes option B incorrect.

C. Omega oxidation:
•   Omega oxidation is another process related to fatty acid metabolism, but it involves the oxidation of fatty acids at the omega end (the terminal carbon of the chain), primarily in the endoplasmic reticulum. It is not involved in the breakdown of phytanic acid.

D. Beta oxidation:
•   Beta oxidation occurs in the mitochondria and is responsible for the breakdown of long-chain fatty acids into acetyl-CoA units. However, Refsum disease specifically relates to the alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids like phytanic acid, not the typical fatty acids involved in beta oxidation.

choices.text: Assertion is correct and reason is also correct
Assertion is correct but reason is wrong
Assertion is wrong but Reason is correct
Both Assertion and Reason is wrong

questions.text:
Assertion mousy order is seen in phenylketonuria
Reason decrease in tyrosine, dopamine, nor adrenaline
Assertion and reasoning
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The assertion is correct. The characteristic "mousy" or "musty" body odor seen in individuals with Phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, particularly phenylacetate and phenylacetylglutamine, which are excreted in sweat and urine. These metabolites have a distinct odor, leading to this diagnostic clinical clue.

The reason is incorrect in explaining the cause of the odor. While it is true that phenylketonuria leads to a decrease in tyrosine, and subsequently dopamine and noradrenaline (since tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines), this biochemical change is not responsible for the mousy odor. The odor is purely due to the accumulation and excretion of aromatic phenylalanine metabolites, not due to the deficiency of downstream neurotransmitters.

questions.text: Xanthenuric acid in urine indicates
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is a crucial coenzyme for many metabolic reactions, particularly those involving amino acid metabolism. One of its roles is as a coenzyme for kynureninase, an enzyme involved in the metabolism of tryptophan through the kynurenine pathway. In vitamin B6 deficiency, this enzyme is impaired, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid, which is then excreted in the urine. Therefore, increased urinary xanthurenic acid is a biochemical marker of vitamin B6 deficiency. This is especially noted after a tryptophan load test.

questions.text: Amino acid not restricted in management of maple syrup urine disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC). This enzyme complex is responsible for the catabolism of the branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs): leucine, isoleucine, and valine. In MSUD, these amino acids and their toxic ketoacid derivatives accumulate, leading to neurological dysfunction, poor feeding, vomiting, and the characteristic maple syrup odor in urine.

Management involves restricting the intake of the branched-chain amino acids — leucine, isoleucine, and valine — while ensuring adequate nutrition. Among the options, methionine is not a branched-chain amino acid, and therefore does not need to be restricted in MSUD. It can be safely included in the diet unless there's a coexisting metabolic disorder

questions.text: Burnt Sugar smell of Urine is because of defect of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Branched Chain Keto Acid Dehydrogenase

The characteristic burnt sugar or maple syrup odor of urine is a hallmark sign of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD). This condition is caused by a defect in the branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC), which is responsible for the breakdown of the branched-chain amino acids: leucine, isoleucine, and valine. When this enzyme complex is deficient, these amino acids and their corresponding ketoacids accumulate in the blood and urine. The build-up of these ketoacids, particularly isoleucine’s byproducts, is responsible for the distinctive sweet, burnt sugar-like odor in the urine. Early diagnosis and dietary management are crucial to prevent severe neurological damage.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman on a camping trip has underestimated the cool evening temperatures, so she wraps herself in a thin sheet of polyester film with a reflective surface (Mylar), also known as an emergency blanket or space blanket. She feels warm immediately. Which heat loss mechanism most likely accounts for the effectiveness of this paper-thin, reflective Mylar blanket?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Most of the heat loss from the body occurs by radiation in the form of infrared heat waves, which is a type of electromagnetic wave. Heat waves radiate from all objects toward the body, and the body radiates heat waves to all surrounding objects. The reflective surface of the Mylar blanket prevents heat loss by reflecting infrared heat waves from the body back to the body, which causes the body to warm. At room temperature, 60% of the heat loss occurs by radiation, 22% by evaporation, 15% by conduction to air, and 3% by conduction to objects. Convection (i.e., air currents) can increase heat loss by removing the unstirred layer of air close to the skin.

choices.text: Conversion of lactic acid into pyruvic acid

questions.text: Most of the energy for strenuous exercise that lasts for more than 5 to 10 seconds but less than 1 to 2 minutes comes from what source?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Most of the extra energy required for strenuous activity that lasts for more than 5 to 10 seconds but less than 1 to 2 minutes is derived from anaerobic glycolysis. Release of energy by glycolysis occurs much more rapidly than oxidative release of energy, which is much too slow to supply the needs of the muscle in the first few minutes of exercise. ATP and phosphocreatine already present in the cells are rapidly depleted in less than 5 to 10 seconds.

choices.text: Increased secretion of ADH from the supraoptic nuclei

questions.text: A patient has nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Which of the following would either be expected or a suggested intervention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

AVPR2 function is impaired in patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, rendering ADH ineffective at increasing H2O reabsorption in the distal nephron. This causes a compensatory increase in the release of ADH from the supraoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus. Patients with diabetes insipidus run the risk of developing hypernatremia, and they produce a large volume of dilute urine.

choices.text: PTH inhibits the production of vitamin D hormones
PTH promotes bone resorption in response to decreased plasma calcium
PTH promotes the movement of calcium from bone fluid to the extracellular fluid
PTH promotes calcium reabsorption in the renal distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: All of the following statements about parathyroid hormone are true EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

(PTH inhibits the production of vitamin D hormones)

This statement is incorrect and thus the exception. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) actually stimulates the production of active vitamin D hormone, specifically calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D₃), in the kidneys. PTH increases the activity of 1α-hydroxylase enzyme in the proximal renal tubules, which converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form. This action helps to increase intestinal absorption of calcium, thereby contributing to the restoration of normal calcium levels in the blood. Therefore, PTH promotes rather than inhibits vitamin D production.

questions.text: Five drugs are listed in the following table (A–d). If these drug molecules are all equally lipophilic, which of the following conditions would produce the highest rate of transport of the drug molecule into a cell by simple diffusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Based on the Fick law, the concentration gradient and molecular weight of a substance both play a role in
diffusion across a membrane. The concentration gradient is greatest in drug C , but since the size of the particle is considered in the permeability coefficient, the smaller particles pass through the membrane easier than large particles, so drug C is the best answer.

questions.text: The figures given below show the changes in the partial pressure of O2 and CO2 as blood flows from the arterial to the venous end of the pulmonary capillaries. Which diagram best depicts the normal relationship between Po2 (red line) and Pco2 (green line) during normal resting conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The pulmonary capillary time is 0.75 to 0.8 seconds in normal resting conditions. The diffusion of O2 and CO2 is complete within the first 0.3 seconds, that is, both gases reach their point of equilibrium within the first one- third of the transit time through the pulmonary capillaries. In fact, CO2 takes less time than O2 to reach its point of equilibrium.

questions.text: Given below is a graph of the electrodermal activity and skin conductance (also k/a Galvanic skin response) on the finger. Which of the following changes will NOT be seen following a fright?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Decreased galvanic skin potential

Sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibers. Fright increases the sympathetic discharge which in turn increases sweat secretion by the sweat glands.
The Galvanic Skin Response (GSR), also named Electrodermal Activity (EDA) and Skin Conductance (SC), is the measure of the continuous variations in the electrical characteristics of the skin, i.e. for instance the conductance, caused by the variation of the human body sweating. Presence of sweat lowers the galvanic skin resistance, increases the galvanic skin potential and increases the electrical conductivity.

questions.text: The figure given below shows the concentration of inulin in different segments of the nephron, expressed as the tubular fluid/ plasma ratio of inulin concentration. If inulin is neither secreted nor reabsorbed, what is the percentage of filtered water that has been reabsorbed prior to the DCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

75%

The TF/P ratio of Inulin concentration is 4.0 in the early distal tubule. Because Inulin is not reabsorbed from the tubule, this means that water reabsorption must have concentrated the Inulin to four times the level in the plasma that was filtered. Therefore, the amount of water remaining in the tubule is only one- fourth of what was filtered, indicating that 75% of the water has been reabsorbed prior to the DCT.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics can be used to differentiate type IIa skeletal muscle fibers from type IIb skeletal muscle fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Type IIa fibers are a hybrid between the type I and type IIb muscle fibers, which means they share different characteristics with each type. Type IIa fibers have a high myoglobin content, which gives them a red color like type I fibers, and a greater endurance than type IIb fibers, since the latter have a low myoglobin content and a white color.

choices.text: Infusion of L-type calcium channel agonist

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with recurrent nausea and vomiting. A gastrointestinal motility disorder is suspected, which is confirmed by an electrogastrogram (see image). At rest (trace X), it shows inappropriately large depolarizations of the intestinal smooth muscle membrane potentials. Trace Y shows her smooth muscle membrane potentials after administration of a drug. Which of the following most likely caused trace Y?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle membranes exhibit an inherent spontaneous activity called slow waves. Their amplitudes and plateau phase durations are decreased by the sympathetic & in this case sympathetic agonist. Decreased slow-wave activity decreases the frequency of spike potential development. This decreases GI smooth muscle contractions. Smooth muscle membrane potential changes are mainly driven by calcium flux instead of sodium flux. Hence, an L-type calcium channel agonist stimulates excitation contraction coupling and would aggravate the patient’s contractions. Acetylcholine (in this case, a drug that increases its lifetime) increases the amplitude and duration of GI slow waves, which increases the frequency of spike potentials and consequently GI smooth muscle contraction. Increasing GI motility makes biological sense with parasympathetic stimulation.

questions.text: Most common cause of inherited coagulopathy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Factor V Leiden mutation

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of coagulopathy, specifically leading to a hypercoagulable state rather than bleeding. It is a genetic mutation in the F5 gene, resulting in a variant of factor V that is resistant to inactivation by activated protein C (APC). This resistance disrupts the normal anticoagulant pathway, leading to increased thrombin generation and a higher risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE). Factor V Leiden is particularly prevalent in Caucasian populations, with heterozygosity occurring in about 5% of individuals. Although it does not typically cause spontaneous bleeding, it is the most common inherited thrombophilia, making it the most frequent inherited coagulopathy in clinical practice.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

  • A. APC – 4. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):
    The APC gene (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) is a tumor suppressor gene involved in the Wnt signaling pathway. Mutations in APC are responsible for Familial Adenomatous Polyposis, an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum, with a nearly 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer if not managed early (often with prophylactic colectomy).
  • B. SMAD – 1. Juvenile polyposis syndrome:
    SMAD4 is one of the key genes mutated in Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition marked by the presence of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. It also increases the risk of GI cancers. SMAD4 is involved in TGF-β signaling, and mutations can disrupt regulation of cell growth.
  • C. SKT11 – 2. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome:
    The STK11 (also known as LKB1) gene is mutated in Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome, another autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mucocutaneous pigmentation and hamartomatous polyps throughout the GI tract. There is also an elevated risk of various cancers including pancreatic, breast, and ovarian.
  • D. TSC – 3. Tuberous sclerosis:
    Mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes (collectively referred to as TSC genes) lead to Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, a disorder marked by benign tumors (hamartomas) in multiple organs, including the brain, kidneys, heart, skin, and lungs. The condition may also present with seizures and developmental delays.

questions.text: Which of the following is required for activation of T cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CD28 is a co-stimulatory receptor that plays a critical role in the activation of T cells. When a naïve T cell recognizes an antigen presented by an antigen-presenting cell (APC) via the MHC–TCR interaction, this signal alone is not sufficient for full T cell activation. A second signal is needed — the co-stimulatory signal — which is provided when CD28 on the T cell binds to B7 molecules (CD80/CD86) on the APC. This co-stimulatory interaction is essential for the full activation, proliferation, and survival of T cells. Without this second signal, T cells become anergic (non-responsive), ensuring that they are only activated in appropriate immune contexts. Hence, CD28 is indispensable for the proper initiation of the adaptive immune response

questions.text: A patient had tonsillitis, takes antibiotics for same, later presents eosinophilia and WBC casts in urine, likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis

Tubulointerstitial nephritis (TIN) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with a recent history of antibiotic use, eosinophilia, and white blood cell (WBC) casts in urine. TIN is an inflammatory condition affecting the interstitium and tubules of the kidney, and it is commonly triggered by hypersensitivity reactions to drugs, particularly antibiotics like penicillins, cephalosporins, or sulfonamides. A classic presentation includes fever, rash, eosinophilia, and signs of acute kidney injury (e.g., increased creatinine). The presence of WBC casts in the urine suggests inflammation of the renal tubules rather than glomeruli or bladder, pointing towards interstitial involvement. Eosinophiluria (eosinophils in urine) is also a hallmark of drug-induced interstitial nephritis, although not always present.

questions.text: A patient with thyroid carcinoma shows amyloid deposits, what is the cell of origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Parafollicular cells

The presence of amyloid deposits in a case of thyroid carcinoma strongly suggests medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), which arises from parafollicular cells, also known as C cells. These neuroendocrine cells are responsible for secreting calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium regulation. In MTC, the excess calcitonin secreted by tumor cells can aggregate into amyloid deposits, which are visible histologically in the stroma of the tumor using Congo red staining, showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light. This unique feature helps differentiate medullary carcinoma from other types of thyroid cancers. Therefore, parafollicular cells are the cell of origin in medullary thyroid carcinoma associated with amyloid deposition

choices.text: Nodular sclerosis manifest as mediastinal lymphnode
RS cells are positive for CD15, CD30, PAX5

questions.text: False about Hodgkin lymphoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Waldeyer ring most commonly involved

This statement is false, making it the correct answer to the question asking for the false statement about Hodgkin lymphoma. The Waldeyer ring (which includes the tonsils and adenoids) is rarely involved in Hodgkin lymphoma. This is in contrast to non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), where Waldeyer ring involvement is relatively common. Hodgkin lymphoma typically affects contiguous lymph node groups, starting with cervical, mediastinal, or axillary nodes, and spreads in an orderly fashion. The relative sparing of extranodal sites like the Waldeyer ring and gastrointestinal tract is a distinguishing feature from NHL. Hence, this statement is incorrect and rightly selected as the false option.

choices.text: Loss of cellular outlines and pyknotic nuclei
Loss of nuclei but maintained cellular outlines
Loss of cellular outlines with intact nuclei
Liquefaction of the tissue and loss of cellular outlines

questions.text: Gross examination of a patient’s heart at autopsy in a patient who died of Myocardial infarction is as follows. Microscopy is likely to show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Loss of nuclei but maintained cellular outlines

The image shows a gross section of the heart with a pale necrotic area—indicative of an infarct. Histologically, this corresponds to coagulative necrosis, the hallmark of early myocardial infarction. In coagulative necrosis, the basic architecture of the dead tissue is preserved for a few days, but cell nuclei are lost due to karyolysis or pyknosis. Thus, under microscopy, you see preserved cell outlines without nuclei, a key feature that helps in dating the infarct to around 12 to 24 hours post-MI. This stage is a classic pathologic feature in infarcted tissues of solid organs like the heart.

questions.text: Flow cytometry of a patient is as follows what is likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

 

B CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia)

The flow cytometry plots reveal a clonal B-cell population that is positive for CD5 and CD23, but negative for CD10, with expression of CD20. This immunophenotype is characteristic of B-cell Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (B-CLL). B-CLL is a mature B-cell neoplasm that paradoxically expresses CD5, a T-cell marker, along with B-cell markers like CD19 and CD20, and importantly CD23. The presence of CD5 and CD23 co-expression is a distinguishing feature that helps differentiate B-CLL from other CD5+ B-cell malignancies, such as mantle cell lymphoma (which is typically CD23 negative).

questions.text: A patient’s hemoglobin is 17g/dl, RBC count is 6.5 million, MCV 80, MCH 29. What is next line of investigation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Serum erythropoietin

The patient presents with elevated hemoglobin (17 g/dL) and a high RBC count (6.5 million/μL), with normal MCV (80 fL) and MCH (29 pg), indicating a normocytic, normochromic erythrocytosis. The next step in evaluating absolute polycythemia (true increase in RBC mass) is to measure serum erythropoietin (EPO). This test helps distinguish between primary polycythemia (e.g., polycythemia vera, PV), where EPO levels are low or suppressed, and secondary causes, where EPO levels are elevated due to chronic hypoxia, tumors producing EPO, or high-altitude living. Identifying the EPO level guides further evaluation and management.

questions.text: The following is the Hematoxylin and Eosin stained section from the heart of a patient after Myocardial Infarction. What can you say about the age of the infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

 

1-2 days

The histopathological image shows myocardial fibers with wavy fibers, loss of striations, and dense neutrophilic infiltrate, which are hallmark features of a myocardial infarction approximately 1 to 2 days old. During this stage, the body mounts an acute inflammatory response: neutrophils begin infiltrating the infarcted area, and irreversible injury to myocytes is evident with early signs of coagulative necrosis. Nuclei are either pyknotic or lost, but the general architecture is still preserved. This timing corresponds with early necrotic changes and peak neutrophilic activity.

questions.text: Immunofluorescene staining pattern from a kidney biopsy from a 35-year-old patient presenting with proteinuria has been shown below. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Lupus Nephritis

The immunofluorescence image demonstrates “full house” positivity—staining for IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, and C3—which is characteristic of Lupus Nephritis. This pattern reflects the deposition of immune complexes containing multiple immunoglobulin classes and complement proteins in the glomeruli, a hallmark feature of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)-related renal involvement. The full house staining helps differentiate lupus nephritis from other causes of glomerulonephritis and strongly points toward a diagnosis of SLE-associated glomerulonephritis

questions.text:
Markers of seminoma-
1. PLAP
2. OCT3/4
3. KIT
4. HCG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

1, 2, 3 only

Seminoma is a type of germ cell tumor of the testis with a well-defined immunohistochemical profile. The key markers for seminoma include:

  • PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): A classic and sensitive marker for seminoma. It is expressed on the cell surface and commonly used in diagnostic pathology.
  • OCT3/4 (Octamer-binding transcription factor 3/4): A nuclear transcription factor essential for maintaining pluripotency in germ cells. It shows strong nuclear staining in seminomas and embryonal carcinoma.
  • KIT (CD117): A receptor tyrosine kinase that is frequently and diffusely positive in seminomas. It plays a role in tumorigenesis and is useful for distinguishing seminoma from other germ cell tumors.

questions.text: 73 year old woman with DM with HTN . Histology image given with special stain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

RESTRICTIVE CM → Amyloid ( congo red stain)
• RCM→ Diastolic dysfunction
• HOCM → young pt collapsing while playing ; diastolic dysfunction
; beta myosin heavy chain , myosin binding protein C mut
• gross→ asymmetrical septal thickening , banana shaped
ventricle
• M/E→ Myofibre disarray
• DCM → Systolic dysfunction ; Titin ( ninja star nuclei on M/E) ,
Lamn A/C mut
Alcohols

questions.text: A 15 yr boy presents with swelling in upper diaphysial part of tibia bone. There was a periosteal reaction & biopsy was performed. The histopathological image is shown below. The IHC was found to be synaptophysin & mic 2 positive. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

 

Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant small round blue cell tumor that most commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically arises in the diaphysis of long bones such as the femur or tibia, often with a periosteal reaction described radiologically as "onion-skinning." Histologically, Ewing sarcoma consists of sheets of uniform small round blue cells with scant cytoplasm. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) plays a crucial role in diagnosis: MIC2 (CD99) positivity is characteristic, showing a membranous staining pattern, and synaptophysin positivity may be present due to its primitive neuroectodermal differentiation

questions.text: An adult male patient presented with shortness of breath, hemoptysis and weight loss. On examination, hilar mass was present. Histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is strongly associated with smoking and typically presents as a central or hilar mass, which fits this patient's clinical picture of shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and weight loss. SCC arises from the bronchial epithelium and can cavitate. Histologically, SCC shows keratinization, intercellular bridges, and polygonal cells. Most importantly, p40 is a highly specific immunohistochemical marker for squamous cell carcinoma. p40 is a more specific isoform of p63, and its strong positivity helps distinguish SCC from other non-small cell lung cancers, particularly adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A female student presents with urticaria following intake of sea food. She wants a non sedating drug since this is her exam time. Which is the preferred antihistamine for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fexofenadine

Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine that is highly effective in treating allergic conditions such as urticaria. It works by blocking H1 histamine receptors but, importantly, does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly, making it non-sedating. This is particularly important for individuals such as students who need to remain alert during exam preparation or daily activities. Its long duration of action and minimal CNS side effects make it the preferred choice in cases where mental alertness must be preserved.

questions.text: What could be the diagnosis for this Image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alopecia areata

Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition that targets hair follicles, leading to non-scarring hair loss in well-circumscribed, round patches, which is typically seen in the image provided. A key feature supporting this diagnosis is the smooth, normal-appearing scalp with complete hair loss in the affected areas, without scaling or inflammation. Another diagnostic hallmark often seen in trichoscopy or biopsy (if provided) is the presence of “exclamation mark” hairs—short broken hairs that are narrower at the base. Alopecia areata is common in younger individuals and is often sudden in onset, aligning with the clinical scenario.

questions.text: A patient farmer/gardener by occupation presented with the following lesion, diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mycetoma

Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection typically seen in individuals with occupations involving soil contact, such as farmers and gardeners. It is caused by either fungi (eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma). The disease classically affects the feet or lower limbs and presents with the triad of swelling, sinus tracts, and discharge containing grains. These grains, visible in exudates, represent colonies of the causative organism. The patient’s occupational history, combined with the characteristic multiple nodular lesions and discharging sinuses, makes mycetoma the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text: A 70 year old patient develop the following lesion over face since 2 years. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC)

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin cancer, particularly in the elderly and those with chronic sun exposure. It typically arises on sun-exposed areas such as the face, nose, or ears, especially in older individuals. Clinically, BCC often presents as a slow-growing, pearly or translucent papule or nodule, frequently with telangiectasia (visible blood vessels) and a central ulcer or crusting, hence the nickname "rodent ulcer". The 2-year gradual progression in an elderly patient with a facial lesion is highly characteristic of BCC. It is locally invasive but rarely metastasizes, making early diagnosis essential for preventing disfigurement.

questions.text: A young lady present s with lacy lesions in oral caity and her proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lichen planus

Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the skin, mucous membranes, hair, and nails. One of its hallmark features in the oral cavity is Wickham striae, which appear as lacy white lesions, most commonly on the buccal mucosa. This is a key clinical clue in the question. Nail involvement is also characteristic, particularly when the proximal nail fold extends onto the nail bed, a phenomenon known as pterygium formation. This results from scarring in the nail matrix and is highly suggestive of lichen planus. The combination of oral lacy lesions and nail changes is classic and diagnostic for lichen planus, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with Toxoplasma gondii infection. Choose the infective stage and the most likely fetal abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Tachyzoites & Hydrocephalus

Toxoplasma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite that can cause congenital toxoplasmosis when a primary infection occurs during pregnancy. The infective stage responsible for fetal transmission is the tachyzoite, the rapidly multiplying form of the parasite. Tachyzoites can cross the placenta and infect the fetus, leading to a range of clinical manifestations. Among these, hydrocephalus is one of the most classic and severe complications seen in congenital toxoplasmosis. This occurs due to inflammation and obstruction of the cerebrospinal fluid pathways caused by parasitic invasion of neural tissues. Other features may include chorioretinitis and intracranial calcifications, but hydrocephalus is a hallmark and frequently tested finding.

questions.text: A malnourished child born to a PLHIV presents with chronic diarrhea. Acid-fast staining of the stool shown in the image. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Cryptosporidium parvum

Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite that causes chronic, watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised individuals, such as children born to PLHIV (people living with HIV). The organism is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and commonly spreads through contaminated water. It is an acid-fast organism, and its oocysts appear as small (4–6 µm), round, pink to red structures on modified Ziehl-Neelsen (acid-fast) staining of stool samples. Cryptosporidium is the most common cause of chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, especially in resource-limited settings. In malnourished children, the combination of immune deficiency and poor sanitation increases susceptibility and disease severity, making it the most likely diagnosis here.

questions.text: A young girl presents with itching and skin nodules over the legs. She is from a village near a fast-flowing river in Africa. Skin snip shows microfilariae. Likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Onchocerca volvulus

Onchocerca volvulus is a filarial nematode transmitted by the bite of the blackfly (genus Simulium), which breeds near fast-flowing rivers, making the girl's geographic location a crucial diagnostic clue. The condition it causes is onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. Patients typically present with intense itching, subcutaneous nodules, and skin changes such as lichenification and depigmentation ("leopard skin"). The diagnosis is confirmed by detecting microfilariae in skin snips, which distinguishes it from other filarial infections where microfilariae are found in blood. In chronic stages, microfilariae may migrate to the eyes, causing visual impairment or blindness—hence the name river blindness.

questions.text: A patient came with blunt injury from farm instrument in chest. Pus from wound shows Gram positive filamentous bacteria which is partially acid fast. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nocardia

Nocardia species are Gram-positive, filamentous, branching bacteria that are partially acid-fast due to the presence of mycolic acids in their cell walls. They are found in soil and decaying organic matter, making trauma with a farm instrument a typical route of inoculation. Nocardiosis often presents as cutaneous or pulmonary infection, particularly after traumatic implantation or in immunocompromised patients. The classic laboratory features—Gram-positive filaments and partial acid-fastness—are key diagnostic clues. Nocardia can cause localized abscesses, draining sinuses, or even disseminated infections. In this case, the chest wound with pus showing characteristic bacterial features strongly points toward Nocardia.

questions.text: Which is not a cold sterilization
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Autoclave

An autoclave is a method of moist heat sterilization that works by applying high-pressure steam at temperatures typically around 121°C for a specific duration. Since it involves high temperatures, it is not considered a cold sterilization method. Cold sterilization refers to techniques that sterilize instruments without the use of heat, making them suitable for heat-sensitive items. The autoclave, on the other hand, is commonly used for sterilizing surgical instruments, laboratory media, and other heat-resistant materials, and is one of the most reliable forms of sterilization—but clearly not a "cold" method.

questions.text: The following one is antibiotic sensitivity testing.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

E test

The E test (Epsilometer test) is a widely used method for antibiotic sensitivity testing. It combines the quantitative aspects of dilution methods with the ease of the disk diffusion method. A plastic strip impregnated with a gradient of antibiotic concentration is placed on an agar plate inoculated with the test organism. After incubation, an elliptical zone of inhibition forms, and the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) can be read directly at the point where the bacterial growth meets the strip. This allows clinicians to determine how sensitive or resistant a microbe is to a particular antibiotic, which is crucial for effective treatment planning.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

This match correctly associates each disease with its causative organism:

  • A. Donovanosis – 4. Klebsiella (Calymmatobacterium) granulomatis
    Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is a chronic sexually transmitted infection caused by K. granulomatis. It presents with painless, progressive ulcerative lesions without lymphadenopathy. The organism is intracellular and forms Donovan bodies on microscopy.
  • B. Pinta – 1. Treponema carateum
    Pinta is a non-venereal treponemal infection endemic to Central and South America. Caused by T. carateum, it affects the skin, causing hypopigmented patches. It is related to yaws and bejel but confined to skin involvement.
  • C. Oroya fever – 2. Bartonella bacilliformis
    This condition, also known as Carrion’s disease, is endemic to Peru and other Andean regions. It is caused by B. bacilliformis, transmitted by sandflies. The acute phase, Oroya fever, presents with hemolytic anemia and fever, while the chronic phase (verruga peruana) features skin eruptions.
  • D. Rat bite fever – 3. Spirillum minus or Streptobacillus moniliformis
    Rat bite fever can be caused by either S. moniliformis (in the West) or S. minus (in Asia). S. moniliformis is a Gram-negative rod often associated with systemic illness following a rat bite. Symptoms include fever, rash, and migratory arthralgia.

questions.text: Which is not a passive immunity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Toxoid

Toxoids are inactivated toxins that stimulate the body's immune system to produce antibodies, but this is a form of active immunity. Active immunity occurs when the body produces its own antibodies in response to an antigen. Since toxoids are used to induce an immune response and the body produces its own antibodies over time, they do not fall under passive immunity.

questions.text: Streptococcus agalactiae causes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Neonatal sepsis

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a common cause of neonatal sepsis, which is a severe infection that can lead to meningitis, pneumonia, and bloodstream infections in newborns. Pregnant women can carry this bacterium in their genital tract, and it can be transmitted to the baby during delivery, leading to serious infections. Neonatal sepsis caused by GBS is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in newborns.

questions.text: Swollen Bartholin opening, vaginal discharge, Clinical picture of PID, Gram negative intra cellular diplococci is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neisseria gonorrhoea

The clinical picture described, including a swollen Bartholin opening, vaginal discharge, and the presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci, is characteristic of gonorrhea, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This bacterium is known for its ability to infect the genital tract, leading to symptoms like vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and abscesses such as a Bartholin cyst. The Gram-negative diplococci seen in a Gram stain of the discharge are typical of this pathogen.

questions.text: Audiogram shown in the image is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The audiogram shown in the image displays a classic “notch” at 4000 Hz, where hearing thresholds are significantly worse compared to other frequencies. This is a hallmark finding of noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL).
In noise trauma, especially due to chronic exposure to loud sounds (e.g., industrial noise, loud music), the cochlear hair cells sensitive to 4000 Hz are particularly vulnerable, leading to the characteristic dip or "notch" at that frequency on the audiogram.
The Air Conduction (AC) and Bone Conduction (BC) curves are overlapping or close, indicating sensorineural type of hearing loss — typical in NIHL.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical feature of allergic rhinitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Allergic rhinitis is an allergic condition characterized by symptoms like sneezing, nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and itching, often accompanied by characteristic signs. Typical features include:

  • Dennie-Morgan (DM) lines: Infraorbital folds or lines under the eyes associated with chronic allergic conditions.

  • Allergic shiners: Dark circles under the eyes due to venous stasis from nasal congestion.

  • Allergic salute: Repeated upward rubbing of the nose, often resulting in a transverse nasal crease.

Otto Veraguth sign:

  • This is not associated with allergic rhinitis.

  • It refers to a specific upward and outward slant of the palpebral fissures, sometimes seen in psychiatric conditions like catatonia or depression, not allergic conditions.

questions.text: A woman has tinnitus and hearing loss with episodic vertigo that WCARES hours each. PTA is shown below. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Endolymphatic hydrops is most classically associated with the triad of episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and tinnitus, exactly as described in the patient. The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows a low-frequency hearing loss (noted by the downward sloping pattern in the low frequencies that improves at higher frequencies), which is a hallmark finding in early endolymphatic hydrops (often seen in Meniere's disease). The hearing loss typically fluctuates, and the vertigo episodes can last from 20 minutes to several hours, matching the description. Tinnitus (ringing in the ear) also accompanies the condition. Hence, the clinical picture along with the audiogram strongly points toward endolymphatic hydrops.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of a foreign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On examination, a reddish pedunculated mass studded with whitish spots was seen hanging in nasal cavity. On nasal endoscopy, mass was seen attached along the under surface of left inferior turbinate, which bled on contact. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. After a clinical diagnosis, he underwent complete excision of the mass after bipolar cauterisation of the base under local anaesthesis.Postoperative histopathology revealed multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation with dense inflammation.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It commonly affects the nasal mucosa and presents as a reddish, friable, polypoidal mass that bleeds easily on touch, exactly like in this case. The history of frequent bathing in ponds is an important clue, as this infection is often associated with exposure to stagnant water. Histopathology reveals multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation surrounded by a dense inflammatory infiltrate, which is the hallmark diagnostic feature seen in the provided microscopic image. Clinically, the presence of a mass studded with white spots (representing mature sporangia) hanging in the nasal cavity is characteristic for rhinosporidiosis.

questions.text: Enlarged orange tonsils as shown in image is found in :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tangier disease


Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a severe deficiency of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. One of the hallmark clinical findings is the enlargement of the tonsils, which appear orange or yellowish due to the deposition of cholesterol esters within the reticuloendothelial cells. The image shows distinctly enlarged, orange-colored tonsils, which is classic for Tangier disease. This color change is unique and helps differentiate it from other causes of tonsillar pathology. Patients may also have hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral neuropathy, and premature cardiovascular disease due to lipid abnormalities.

questions.text: Aspiration in the respiratory tract prevented by supraglottic and cough reflex, these reflexes are sluggish in alcohol patient, Which of the following nerve is common injured:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal laryngeal nerve

  • The internal laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X). It innervates the mucosa of the larynx above the vocal cords and plays a crucial role in the cough reflex and protective airway reflexes, including those preventing aspiration.

  • When someone is intoxicated, the reflexes involved in protecting the airway, such as the supraglottic reflex and the cough reflex, can be sluggish or impaired. This can lead to an increased risk of aspiration. Alcohol consumption often affects the function of the internal laryngeal nerve, compromising these reflexes.

questions.text: If OAE is negative in one of the patient, next step will be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tympanometry.

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) are a test of the inner ear (cochlea), specifically assessing the function of the outer hair cells in the cochlea. A negative OAE result typically suggests a problem with the cochlear function, most commonly indicating sensorineural hearing loss or middle ear dysfunction, such as fluid in the middle ear.

When a negative OAE result is obtained, the next step is often to perform tympanometry, which is a test to evaluate the middle ear function. Tympanometry helps determine if there is any middle ear pathology, such as fluid, eustachian tube dysfunction, or a perforated eardrum. It assesses the mobility of the eardrum and the pressure within the middle ear, which can help clarify the cause of the negative OAE.

questions.text: Comment on the grade of retracted tympanic membrane shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Grade I retraction of the tympanic membrane is characterized by mild retraction without touching or adhering to the middle ear structures like the long process of the incus or the promontory. In the image, the TM appears slightly retracted but not plastered against middle ear structures, and there is still an identifiable cone of light without significant distortion. This indicates that the retraction is mild and is consistent with a Grade I retraction. At this stage, there is usually no significant ossicular involvement or hearing loss, and the eardrum retains some mobility.

choices.text: Compound hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule
Compound hypermetropic astigmatism against the rule

questions.text: After completion of retinoscopy of right eye of a child, it was noted that the vertical axis power was +4 dioptres and horizontal axis was + 6 dioptres. What will be the refractive error for the right eye of the child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The refractive error in this case is compound hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule (Option B). The child’s right eye shows a difference in the refractive power between the vertical axis (+4 dioptres) and the horizontal axis (+6 dioptres), which indicates astigmatism. The astigmatism is hypermetropic, meaning both axes are hyperopic (farsighted), and the vertical axis has a lower power (+4 D) compared to the horizontal axis (+6 D). Since the vertical axis has less power and is associated with more curvature (i.e., more positive refractive error), the astigmatism is "with the rule" (the axis of the greatest power is aligned vertically). This pattern is common in children and is classified as compound hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule.

choices.text: Immediate X-ray to know any intraocular foreign body (IOFB)
Urgent perforation repair with removal of IOFB
Prophylactic systemic antibiotics can be given

questions.text: A worker presented with sudden onset of vision loss with pain and redness after an explosion in metal industry where he works.  On examination, the doctor noted vision to be only Perception of light present. There was scleral perforation in nasal part of eye with uveal tissue show.  What is not done in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Irrigation with saline

In the case of a scleral perforation with uveal tissue showing, irrigation with saline (Option B) should be avoided. This is because saline irrigation can cause further complications, such as spreading contaminants or bacteria into the eye, increasing the risk of infection. Instead, the priority is to prevent contamination and manage the injury through proper surgical intervention. Irrigation could worsen the injury or interfere with the necessary surgical repair, which is why it's not indicated in this scenario.

questions.text:
Select the true statements regarding Primary angle closure disease

1.    Age is important risk factor

2.    It has more symptoms than open angle spectrum

3.    Ocular Hypertension comes in this category

4.    Cycloplegics are avoided until laser iridotomy is done

5.    If IOP is normal with no optic disc changes, its termed Primary angle closure suspect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The true statements regarding Primary angle closure disease (PACD) are:

1. Age is an important risk factor – True. Age is a significant risk factor for PACD, particularly in individuals over 40 years of age, with the risk increasing with age due to changes in the lens and anterior chamber of the eye.

2. It has more symptoms than open-angle glaucoma – True. PACD often presents with acute symptoms, such as pain, redness, blurred vision, and nausea, which are more noticeable compared to the asymptomatic nature of open-angle glaucoma, where the condition is often discovered incidentally during a routine eye exam.

4. Cycloplegics are avoided until laser iridotomy is done – True. In acute angle closure cases, cycloplegics are avoided initially because they can cause pupil dilation, which can worsen the blockage of the angle. Laser iridotomy is performed first to relieve the pressure before cycloplegics are considered for further treatment.

5. If IOP is normal with no optic disc changes, it's termed Primary angle closure suspect – True. In PACD, if the intraocular pressure (IOP) is normal and there are no signs of optic disc changes, but the angle is narrow or there is other suspicion of angle closure, it is termed Primary angle closure suspect (PACS).

Incorrect Responses:

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given gaze positions of a patient who presented with c/o diplopia ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The image shows the classic eye movement abnormalities consistent with a left third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy. In the nine gaze positions, the left eye demonstrates restricted movement in upward gaze (superior rectus), downward gaze (inferior rectus), and adduction (medial rectus). This pattern indicates dysfunction of the extraocular muscles innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Additionally, ptosis (drooping of the left eyelid) is evident, which results from involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris, also supplied by CN III. These signs together point clearly to a left-sided third nerve palsy, which would commonly present with diplopia due to eye misalignment and inability to move the eye in most directions except abduction and slight depression (due to preserved function of lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, supplied by CN VI and IV respectively).

questions.text: Match the retina layers with the animated pic
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The retina is a multilayered structure that processes visual information through a complex circuit of photoreceptors, interneurons, and ganglion cells. In the provided image, the label ‘a’ corresponds to the Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE), the outermost layer that supports photoreceptors and absorbs excess light. The label ‘b’ matches the Ganglion cell layer, which contains the output neurons of the retina whose axons form the optic nerve. The ‘d’ layer corresponds to the Outer Nuclear Layer, which contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones). The label ‘c’ indicates the Outer Plexiform Layer, where synapses occur between photoreceptors and bipolar cells. Thus, the correct matching of anatomical features to labels is: 1-a (RPE), 2-b (Ganglion), 3-d (Outer nuclear), 4-c (Outer plexiform).

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in high myopia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior staphyloma (Option D) is a characteristic finding in high myopia. It is an outpouching or thinning of the posterior part of the eye, often seen in individuals with severe myopia. This condition is caused by the elongation of the eyeball, which leads to the stretching of the retina and sclera, creating the staphyloma. The presence of posterior staphyloma is a hallmark of high myopia and can contribute to various complications, including macular degeneration and retinal tears.

questions.text: A 15 yr old boy on routine examination was seen in clinic. Incidentally, the doctor noted, a yellow colored deposition at the fovea, resembling an “egg yolk”. Which investigation will provide the diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The yellow "egg yolk" deposition at the fovea, which is a characteristic feature of Best's disease (also known as Best vitelliform macular dystrophy), is best diagnosed through an Electrooculogram (EOG) (Option C). EOG measures the function of the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). In Best's disease, the EOG typically shows a characteristic abnormality called a "loss of the Arden ratio", which helps confirm the diagnosis. This test is especially useful for diseases involving the RPE and macula.

questions.text: All are the things to be noted in a patient of congenital glaucoma of 1 year old during examination except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Goldmann tonometry (Option B) is not typically used for measuring intraocular pressure in young children, especially in cases of congenital glaucoma. This method requires cooperation from the patient, which is difficult in infants and toddlers. For 1-year-old children, indirect methods such as applanation tonometry or tonopen are preferred because they can be more easily used on uncooperative patients. Goldmann tonometry, which involves placing a probe on the cornea, is generally used for adults or older children who can cooperate with the procedure.

questions.text: Truelove and Witte criteria used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute severe ulcerative colitis

The Truelove and Witts criteria are clinical guidelines used to assess the severity of ulcerative colitis, specifically to classify cases as mild, moderate, or severe. This classification is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment strategy, particularly in distinguishing acute severe ulcerative colitis (ASUC) which often requires hospitalization and may necessitate intravenous steroids or surgical intervention. The criteria consider several clinical parameters: frequency of bloody stools per day, body temperature, heart rate, hemoglobin levels, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). A patient is typically considered to have severe disease if they have more than six bloody stools per day, along with systemic signs of toxicity such as fever (>37.8°C), tachycardia (>90 bpm), anemia (Hb <10.5 g/dL), and elevated ESR (>30 mm/hr). These criteria help clinicians identify patients at higher risk of complications and guide decisions about escalation of therapy, such as biologics or surgery.

choices.text: Anti-IgA tissue transglutaminase (TTG) is a key diagnostic marker
Modified Marsh criteria is used for histological classification
Anti-tTg & gliadin antibodies are highly specific for celiac disease
HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements about celiac disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are not the genetic markers associated with celiac disease. The correct genetic associations are HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, which are present in nearly all individuals with celiac disease. Approximately 90–95% of patients carry the HLA-DQ2 haplotype, and most of the remaining patients carry HLA-DQ8. These genes encode specific MHC class II molecules that present gluten-derived peptides to T cells, initiating the autoimmune response in susceptible individuals. HLA-DQ6 and DQ11, on the other hand, are not associated with celiac disease and their presence would typically argue against the diagnosis in most cases. Therefore, this makes option D the correct answer to a question asking for the incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. Lab investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be signs of underlying dyselectrolytemia except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cerebral edema because it is not a common manifestation of dyselectrolytemia, especially in the context of hypokalemia or dehydration-related electrolyte imbalances. Cerebral edema typically arises in conditions such as hyponatremia, diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) after overly rapid correction, or hepatic encephalopathy, rather than direct electrolyte disturbances involving potassium, calcium, or magnesium. In this case, the patient’s primary disturbance is hypokalemia, which does not typically cause cerebral edema. Instead, hypokalemia leads to neuromuscular and cardiac symptoms due to altered membrane excitability.

choices.text: IV adenosine 6 mg bolus followed by saline push

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency department unconscious and hypotensive. His ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Synchronized DC cardioversion, which is the treatment of choice for unstable patients with tachyarrhythmias, regardless of the QRS complex width. In this case, the patient is unconscious and hypotensive, which are clear signs of hemodynamic instability. Narrow complex tachycardia, likely a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), can cause such instability if the ventricular rate is very high. The Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines recommend immediate synchronized cardioversion in all tachycardic patients who are unstable, to quickly restore a perfusing rhythm. Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock in sync with the R wave, minimizing the risk of inducing ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text: Metabolic syndrome will include all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hip circumference

Hip circumference because it is not a criterion used in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Instead, waist circumference, which reflects central (abdominal) obesity, is a key component. Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk for cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. According to guidelines such as the National Cholesterol Education Program – Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III) and the International Diabetes Federation (IDF), the criteria include:

1. Abdominal obesity (measured by waist circumference, not hip circumference),

2. Elevated blood pressure,

3. Elevated fasting blood glucose,

4. Low HDL cholesterol, and

5. High triglyceride levels.

A diagnosis is typically made when three or more of these criteria are present. Hip circumference is not a standard parameter in this context, as it doesn’t specifically indicate visceral fat, which is more strongly linked to metabolic risk.

questions.text: 25/M, H/O VOMITING BROUGHT TO ED. O/E Pt BP : Low, What can be seen ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Metabolic alkalosis, which is a classic consequence of prolonged vomiting. Vomiting leads to the loss of hydrochloric acid (HCl) from the stomach, resulting in a hydrogen ion (H⁺) deficit. This loss causes the blood to become more alkaline, hence producing metabolic alkalosis. In addition, vomiting also leads to the loss of sodium, potassium, and chloride, contributing to hypovolemia (low blood pressure) and hypokalemia, which further maintain the alkalotic state. The kidneys attempt to compensate by retaining bicarbonate and excreting hydrogen, worsening the alkalosis in volume-depleted states.
