This loss causes the blood to become more alkaline, hence producing metabolic alkalosis. In addition, vomiting also leads to the loss of sodium, potassium, and chloride, contributing to hypovolemia (low blood pressure) and hypokalemia, which further maintain the alkalotic state. The kidneys attempt to compensate by retaining bicarbonate and excreting hydrogen, worsening the alkalosis in volume-depleted states.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with c/o symmetrical joint pains with morning stiffness of hands and ankle. Likely Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

RA is a chronic autoimmune disease that characteristically presents with symmetrical polyarthritis, particularly affecting the small joints such as those of the hands (MCP and PIP joints) and feet. One of the hallmark symptoms is morning stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes, which improves with activity—a key clinical clue in this case. The involvement of both hands and ankles, along with the symmetrical pattern, strongly supports a diagnosis of RA. The disease is more common in middle-aged females, further supporting the diagnosis. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent joint deformity and systemic complications

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the emergency department due to fainting. On examination, he has low blood pressure, S1, and S2 are muffled, and absent Y descent was seen in JVP. Which of the following is the treatment option in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Echocardiographic guided pericardiocentesis


Echocardiographic-guided pericardiocentesis is the primary treatment for cardiac tamponade leading to compression of the heart chambers and diastolic  ollapse of ventricles. This compression results in symptoms such as fainting (syncope), low blood pressure (hypotension), muffled heart sounds (S1 and S2), and an absent Y descent in the jugular venous pulse (JVP). Pericardiocentesis, guided by echocardiography, allows for the drainage of the pericardial fluid, relieving the pressure on the heart and improving hemodynamic stability.

questions.text: A patient after RTA underwent ileal resection. He presents with fatigue, which of the following will not be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Microcytic hypochromic anemia


After a complete ileal resection, it is unlikely for the patient to have microcytic anemia. Instead, the patient is more likely to develop macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum and requires intrinsic factor, a protein produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, for absorption. Following ileal resection, the impaired absorption of vitamin B12 leads to this type of deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with persistent hypertension and muscle weakness. Laboratory tests reveal low serum potassium levels and metabolic alkalosis. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Liddle syndrome causes hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension. It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to a gain-of-function mutation in the ENaC gene, leading to increased sodium retention and volume expansion, which suppresses renin and aldosterone, resulting in hypokalemia. Treatment involves ENaC blockers like amiloride or triamterene; spironolactone is ineffective.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with respiratory distress and cardiogenic shock, which type of respiratory failure is primarily caused by underperfusion of respiratory muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Type 4 respiratory failure
Type 4 respiratory failure, also known as respiratory muscle pump failure, occurs due to
underperfusion of respiratory muscles, particularly in conditions such as cardiogenic shock. In
cardiogenic shock, decreased cardiac output leads to inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles,
resulting in respiratory distress. Management involves addressing the underlying cause of shock,
such as with interventions like Impella or inotropes, and providing respiratory support with
interventions like endotracheal intubation and intermittent positive pressure ventilation.

questions.text: One year ago, a 24-year-old woman had an episode of diplopia of 2 weeks’ duration. The symptoms resolved completely. Currently, she complains of left arm weakness but no headache. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Multiple neurologic deficits separated in space and time in a young patient are suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Symptoms lasting longer than 24 hours as well as the patient’s age makes transient ischemic attacks (even if recurrent) less likely to be the cause of her
symptoms. A subarachnoid hemorrhage will often present with a “thunder clap headache” or “the
worst headache” of the patient’s life and is usually an isolated event. A complicated migraine can
include symptoms such as changes in vision and arm weakness but with or before the onset of the
headache.

choices.text: Treatment with fluoxetine for 9 to 12 months

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is noted by his family members to be forgetful and become disoriented. He has difficulty making it to the bathroom in time and complains of feeling as though “he is walking like he was drunk.” Which of the following therapies is most likely to improve his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt

Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt, which is the treatment of choice for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). NPH classically presents in older adults with the triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment (often summarized as “wet, wobbly, and wacky”). The patient’s symptoms of ataxic gait (“walking like he was drunk”), memory issues, disorientation, and urinary incontinence are strongly indicative of NPH. In this condition, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) accumulates in the ventricles of the brain without a marked increase in pressure, leading to ventricular dilation and compression of surrounding brain structures. A VP shunt diverts CSF from the ventricles to the peritoneal cavity, relieving symptoms and improving function in many cases, especially gait.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to your clinic for her annual physical examination. On examination, you note neck fullness. When you palpate her thyroid, it is enlarged, smooth, rubbery, and nontender. The patient is asymptomatic. You send her for thyroid function testing: her T4 , free T4 , and T3 are normal, but her TSH is slightly elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hashimoto thyroiditis

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most likely diagnosis in this 42-year-old woman who presents with a diffusely enlarged, non-tender, smooth, and rubbery thyroid gland, along with subclinical hypothyroidism (normal T4, T3, but elevated TSH). Hashimoto thyroiditis is a chronic autoimmune condition in which the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, gradually leading to decreased thyroid hormone production. In early stages of the disease, thyroid hormone levels may remain within the normal range, but TSH can be mildly elevated, indicating that the pituitary gland is compensating for subtle declines in thyroid function. The thyroid may appear enlarged and rubbery on palpation due to lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis. The absence of tenderness helps distinguish it from other causes of thyroid enlargement, like subacute thyroiditis. This condition is more common in middle-aged women and is often asymptomatic in early stages, making it a frequent incidental finding during routine physical examinations

choices.text: Inferior branch of the left middle cerebral artery
Superior branch of the left middle cerebral artery
Main trunk of the left middle cerebral artery

questions.text: A 50-year-old banker presents to the emergency department with sudden onset speech difficulties during a sales meeting. Upon examination, he is found to speak fluently but lacks comprehension or understanding of his speech. Which blood vessel is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Inferior branch of the left middle cerebral artery In this scenario, the
patient's presentation of fluent speech without comprehension suggests the involvement of the
inferior branch of the left middle cerebral artery. This branch supplies the posterior portion of the
frontal lobe and the temporal lobe, including Wernicke's area, which is crucial for language
comprehension. Damage to this area leads to receptive dysphasia, where the patient's speech
remains fluent but lacks meaning or understanding, termed as jargon speech.

questions.text: A patient with polyuria, polydipsia, and drowsiness shows ABG: pH 7.15, HCO3 - 12, Na+ 135, Cl- 95. Likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Diabetic Ketoacidosis
 

The patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and drowsiness, along with ABG findings of low pH (7.15) and low bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻ 12), indicating a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. These clinical and biochemical features are classic for Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), a serious complication of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (most often type 1). In DKA, insulin deficiency leads to increased lipolysis and ketone production (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate), resulting in metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. Additionally, hyperglycemia causes osmotic diuresis, leading to dehydration, polyuria, and polydipsia. Drowsiness or altered mental status occurs due to severe acidosis and dehydration. Sodium may appear mildly low or normal due to dilutional effects, and chloride is often relatively low due to the shift in anion balance caused by accumulating ketoacids.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with interstitial lung disease (ILD) undergoes spirometry. Which of the following patterns is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

FEV₁/FVC > 0.7, FVC < 80%

In interstitial lung disease (ILD), a restrictive lung pattern is typically observed on spirometry. ILD causes inflammation and fibrosis of the lung interstitium, which reduces lung compliance and volume. This results in a decrease in forced vital capacity (FVC) due to reduced lung expansion. However, because both FEV₁ (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) and FVC are reduced proportionally, the FEV₁/FVC ratio is typically normal or even increased (i.e., > 0.7). A reduced FVC (< 80% of predicted) in combination with a preserved or elevated FEV₁/FVC ratio is characteristic of restrictive lung disease, such as ILD.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with severe ARDS is on mechanical ventilation. His PaO2 is 58 mmHg on FiO2 100%. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increase PEEP

In patients with severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), the goal of mechanical ventilation is to optimize oxygenation while minimizing ventilator-induced lung injury. This patient has a PaO₂ of 58 mmHg despite receiving 100% FiO₂, indicating refractory hypoxemia. At such high levels of FiO₂, oxygen toxicity becomes a concern, so further increasing FiO₂ is not a safe or effective option. Instead, the best step is to increase Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP). PEEP helps keep alveoli open at the end of expiration, improves alveolar recruitment, and enhances oxygenation by reducing shunt and improving ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) matching. In ARDS, many alveoli collapse (atelectasis), and increasing PEEP counteracts this, thereby improving oxygenation.

questions.text: Which sleep disorder has high PaCO₂ during wakefulness & high apnea-hypopnea index (AHI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS)

Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS), also known as Pickwickian syndrome, is characterized by chronic daytime hypoventilation (elevated PaCO₂ > 45 mmHg) in obese individuals (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) in the absence of other causes of hypoventilation. It is often associated with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and shows an elevated apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) on sleep studies. The pathophysiology involves blunted ventilatory response to hypercapnia and hypoxia, increased work of breathing, and often coexisting upper airway obstruction. As a result, patients have persistently high PaCO₂ during wakefulness and sleep-disordered breathing patterns. This combination of chronic hypoventilation and sleep apnea makes OHS unique among sleep disorders.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with diabetes presents with vague epigastric discomfort. ECG shows T wave inversions in V2-V4, and troponin-I is elevated. Coronary angiography shows 70% LAD stenosis without complete occlusion. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

This patient has elevated troponin-I, T wave inversions in leads V2–V4, and significant coronary artery disease (70% LAD stenosis) — findings that are diagnostic of a Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI). NSTEMI is a type of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) caused by partial occlusion of a coronary artery leading to myocardial ischemia and injury, which results in elevated cardiac biomarkers (e.g., troponin) without ST-segment elevation on ECG. The presence of T wave inversions in the anterior leads (V2–V4) further supports ischemia in the LAD territory. Diabetic patients often have atypical presentations, such as vague epigastric discomfort instead of classic chest pain, making it crucial to consider cardiac causes even with nonspecific symptoms.

questions.text: A cirrhotic patient develops ascites. Paracentesis shows SAAG = 1.4 and ascitic protein = 0.8 g/dL. Which condition is most consistent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Cirrhosis with portal hypertension

This patient’s ascitic fluid analysis shows a Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) of 1.4 g/dL and a low ascitic fluid protein concentration of 0.8 g/dL. A SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to portal hypertension, which is commonly caused by cirrhosis. The low ascitic protein (<2.5 g/dL) suggests that the fluid is a transudate, typical of cirrhosis-related ascites due to increased hydrostatic pressure without significant inflammation or protein leakage. Cirrhosis is by far the most common cause of high-SAAG, low-protein ascites and fits perfectly with the clinical context given.

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding Anemia of CKD is FALSE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

EPO must be started if Transferrin saturation is < 20 %

The statement in option D is FALSE because erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs), such as erythropoietin (EPO), are not initiated based solely on transferrin saturation (TSAT) levels. In anemia of chronic kidney disease (CKD), the primary factor causing anemia is erythropoietin deficiency, and treatment with EPO is typically considered when there is significant anemia (low hemoglobin levels), not just based on a low TSAT. TSAT is an indirect marker of iron availability, and while iron deficiency can contribute to anemia, EPO is more appropriately used when hemoglobin levels are low and not simply when TSAT is under 20%.

questions.text: POST GASTRECTOMY PATIENT COMPLAINS OF LOWER LIMB WEAKNESS, MOST LIKELY CAUSE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Vitamin B12.

After a gastrectomy (partial or total removal of the stomach), patients are at significant risk of developing Vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of intrinsic factor, a glycoprotein produced by parietal cells in the stomach. Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of Vitamin B12 in the terminal ileum. Without it, even if dietary intake is adequate, B12 cannot be absorbed efficiently, leading to deficiency over time. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and can present as subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which includes symptoms like lower limb weakness, numbness, tingling, and impaired coordination due to demyelination of the posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord. Hematological manifestations like megaloblastic anemia may also occur but neurological symptoms can present even in the absence of anemia. Since B12 stores in the liver can last for a couple of years, these symptoms often appear gradually and are a late complication of gastrectomy.

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.text: A 20 year old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. USG shows distention of the portal vein and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been initiated. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Perform an endoscopy to look for varices.

The most appropriate next step in this scenario is upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy to evaluate for esophageal or gastric varices, which are a common and life-threatening cause of hematemesis in patients with portal hypertension, especially in chronic alcoholics. The distended portal vein and hyperechoic liver on ultrasound are suggestive of chronic liver disease and portal hypertension, both of which increase the risk for variceal bleeding. Early endoscopy (within 12 hours) is critical not just for diagnosis but also for therapeutic interventions like variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy, which are key in controlling bleeding. Pantoprazole is given empirically to cover the possibility of peptic ulcers, but in this clinical context, variceal bleeding must be urgently ruled out or treated to reduce mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B is not a well-established risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, though it is strongly associated with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Chronic Hepatitis B infection primarily causes inflammation and malignancy in hepatocytes rather than the biliary epithelium. While some studies suggest a possible weak association between viral hepatitis and cholangiocarcinoma, it is not a direct or major risk factor like other conditions that involve chronic inflammation or structural anomalies of the bile ducts. Therefore, among the given choices, Hepatitis B is the best answer as it is the least directly linked to cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy. The histopathology reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscular. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Radical/wide excision of fossa.

In a case where gallbladder carcinoma is found incidentally after cholecystectomy and the tumor has invaded the muscularis layer (T1b stage), the recommended next step is radical re-excision of the gallbladder fossa along with segment IVB and V of the liver and regional lymphadenectomy. T1b tumors have a significantly higher risk of lymph node involvement and local spread compared to T1a tumors (which are confined to the mucosa). Simple cholecystectomy is considered adequate for T1a tumors, but radical excision improves survival and local control for T1b and higher-stage cancers. Therefore, the appropriate management after incidental discovery of T1b gallbladder cancer is a radical/wide resection of the fossa, making this the correct and evidence-based next step

questions.text: What cancer being operated here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Explanation:

  • Whipple’s procedure is the standard surgery for carcinoma head of pancreas. 

  • It may also be done for periampullary carcinoma and distal CBD tumors, but classically it is for pancreatic head carcinoma.

  • Carcinoma GB usually requires extended cholecystectomy or hepatopancreatoduodenectomy (not standard Whipple). 

  • Cholangiocarcinoma (hilar) usually requires hepatic resection, not Whipple. 

  • Stomach cancer is treated with gastrectomy, not Whipple.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Wilms tumor is true, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Lung metastasis is rare and occurs late.

Wilms tumor is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children.

  • A. Presents as an abdominal mass: This is true. Wilms tumor often presents as an abdominal mass, and it is typically detected by the parents or healthcare providers during a physical examination.

  • B. Most commonly seen <5 years of age: This is true. Wilms tumor is most commonly diagnosed in children under the age of 5, and the peak incidence is between 2 and 3 years.

  • C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and surgery: This is true. Wilms tumor has a relatively high cure rate, especially when detected early. Surgery to remove the tumor and chemotherapy are the mainstays of treatment, and most children recover.

  • D. Lung metastasis is rare and occurs late: This statement is false. Lung metastasis is actually not rare in Wilms tumor, and it can occur early in the course of the disease. Lung metastasis is one of the most common sites of distant spread in Wilms tumor, especially in higher-stage disease.

questions.text: YOUNG MALE WITH PAIN IN LEFT ILIAC FOSSA, HISTORY OF OCASSIONAL HEMATURIA. BEST INVESTIGATION
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Explanation:

  • The patient is a young male with pain in left iliac fossa (suggesting ureteric colic) and occasional hematuria (common with urinary stones).

  • The best investigation for suspected urolithiasis is Non-contrast CT (NCCT KUB) because:

    1. Highest sensitivity & specificity (~95–98%) for detecting urinary stones.

    2. Detects both radio-opaque and radiolucent stones (e.g., uric acid, cystine, xanthine), unlike X-ray which misses radiolucent stones.

    3. Provides information on stone size, location, number, density (HU units) → helps guide management.

    4. Rapid and non-invasive.

    Other options:

    • X-ray KUB: Detects only radio-opaque stones (calcium oxalate, phosphate, struvite) but misses radiolucent stones.

    • Ultrasound (USG): Good for screening, no radiation, but less sensitive for small and ureteric stones.

    • Ureteroscopy: Invasive, not a first-line diagnostic tool (used for treatment/confirmation).

questions.text: During the laparoscopic cholecystectomy the surgeon asks you what is the angle between camera (telescope) and working instrument-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

AZIMUTH ANGLE.

During laparoscopic cholecystectomy (or any laparoscopic surgery), the relationship between the camera (telescope) and the working instruments is important for precision and visibility.

  • Azimuth angle refers to the angle between the camera (telescope) and the working instrument, particularly the horizontal angle around the axis. It describes the lateral orientation of the camera relative to the instrument, helping in directing the instruments in the right direction while maintaining optimal visibility.

  • Elevation angle would refer to the vertical angle between the camera and the instrument, but it does not specifically describe the angle between the camera and the instrument as asked in the question.

  • Manipulation angle is not a standard term in laparoscopic surgery. It might refer to the movement or manipulation of the instrument, but it doesn't describe the angle between the telescope and instrument.

  • Working angle generally refers to the angle at which a working instrument is positioned relative to the surgical site, but it’s not typically used to describe the relationship between the camera and the instrument in laparoscopic settings.

questions.text: MOST DANGEROUS NERVE INJURY IN THYROID SURGERY:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Bilateral RLN complete.

The most dangerous nerve injury during thyroid surgery is complete bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury. The RLN innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. Complete bilateral damage causes paralysis of both vocal cords in a median (midline) position, leading to severe airway obstruction and life-threatening stridor immediately after surgery. This can result in acute respiratory distress requiring urgent tracheostomy or reintubation to secure the airway. Because of its critical effect on breathing, bilateral complete RLN injury is considered the most dangerous complication compared to other types of RLN injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN 2b
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Parathyroid hyperplasia.

Parathyroid hyperplasia is not a feature of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B). It is characteristic of MEN 1 and MEN 2A, where hyperparathyroidism is commonly seen due to parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia. In contrast, MEN 2B typically does not involve the parathyroid glands, making this option the correct answer. The absence of parathyroid disease is an important distinguishing feature between MEN 2A and MEN 2B. Thus, when parathyroid hyperplasia is present, MEN 2B is unlikely

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma presents with ulceration on skin and erythema of surrounding skin. Nipple retraction was also present. This patient is classified under which stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Stage 3.

This patient is best classified as Stage 3 breast cancer due to the presence of skin ulceration, erythema, and nipple retraction, all of which are features of locally advanced disease. Specifically, skin involvement such as ulceration or edema (including peau d’orange) and nipple retraction indicates a T4 lesion, which automatically places the cancer in at least Stage 3, regardless of nodal status (if distant metastasis is absent). Stage 3 includes T4 tumors that may involve chest wall or skin and may or may not have lymph node involvement, but without distant metastasis (M0). Therefore, based on clinical presentation and absence of distant metastasis, Stage 3 is the most appropriate classification.

There is a word erythema, therefore it can be T4D also. So although T4B is right  but can it be placed in T4D as well. All T are stage 3, Presence or absence of Node will not change the stage. Stage 3 is best answer

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with left lower lip weakness following a recent parotid gland surgery. Considering the surgical history and current symptoms, what is the most likely site of the lesion pausing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Main trunk of facial nerve

The most likely site of the lesion is the main trunk of the facial nerve, which is particularly vulnerable during parotid gland surgery, especially if the surgery is extensive or involves the deep lobe. The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) enters the parotid gland and then branches into five main divisions: temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal), and cervical. An injury to the main trunk before it divides can cause weakness in multiple areas of facial expression, including the lower lip, which is controlled by the marginal mandibular branch. Since the main trunk lies within or near the parotid gland, damage during parotidectomy can lead to the kind of broad facial muscle weakness seen here, including the lower lip.

questions.text: Which needs immediate intervention in the triage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Red.

In the triage color coding system, Red represents patients who are in a critical condition but are salvageable with immediate intervention. These individuals typically have life-threatening injuries such as severe bleeding, airway obstruction, or shock, and require urgent medical treatment to survive. Prioritizing Red-tagged patients is essential in mass casualty situations because rapid intervention can significantly improve their outcomes. They are the first priority in emergency response.

questions.text: An elderly man comes to surgery OPD with the given image the most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The image shows a pearly nodule with central ulceration located near the inner canthus of the eye, a classic presentation of a rodent ulcer, which is a clinical term for basal cell carcinoma (BCC). BCC is the most common skin cancer, typically affecting sun-exposed areas in elderly individuals. It grows slowly and rarely metastasizes, but it can cause significant local tissue destruction. The “rolled edge” appearance with a central ulcer is highly characteristic. BCCs are called rodent ulcers because they “gnaw” away at surrounding tissue in a slow but destructive fashion.

questions.text: Calculate BSA for a patient with burn involving the anterior part of chest and abdomen, Right arm and Right thigh (circumferential).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

36%.

The body surface area (BSA) involved in burns can be estimated using the "Rule of Nines" or the modified version. According to the rule, the anterior chest and abdomen together account for 18% of BSA, the right arm (circumferential) accounts for 9% (as the circumferential involvement affects the whole limb), and the right thigh (circumferential) also accounts for 9%. Adding these together gives 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right arm) + 9% (right thigh) = 36% BSA involved in the burn.

questions.text:
Which of the following are done in Breast Conservation Surgery?

1. Wide local excision

2. Axillary node dissection can be done

3. Frozen section (biopsy) can be done during surgery

4. Post-operative radiotherapy optional
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

1, 2, and 3

Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS) involves removing the cancer while preserving as much of the breast as possible. It typically includes the following components:

1. Wide local excision 

This is the main surgical step in BCS where the tumor is removed with a margin of normal tissue.

2. Axillary node dissection can be done 

Yes, either axillary lymph node dissection or sentinel lymph node biopsy may be performed during BCS, depending on nodal status.

3. Frozen section (biopsy) can be done during surgery 

This is sometimes used intraoperatively to assess margins or sentinel lymph nodes.

4. Post-operative radiotherapy optional 

Incorrect: Radiotherapy is not optional; it is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence.

Breast conservation surgery (BCS) aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much of the breast tissue as possible. This includes procedures such as wide local excision, which involves removing the tumor along with a margin of healthy tissue (Option 1). Axillary node dissection can also be performed during BCS if there is a concern about the spread of cancer to the lymph nodes (Option 2). Frozen section biopsy may be done during surgery to check for clear margins, ensuring that no cancer cells remain at the edges of the excised tissue (Option 3). These procedures are all integral to ensuring the best possible outcomes in BCS.

questions.text:
A patient comes with dull aching pain in both legs. He gives a history of prolonged standing and tortuous veins in the legs. Which of the below mentioned tests are done for saphenofemoral incompetence?

A. Brodie Trendelenburg Test

B. Morrissey's test

C. Fegan's test

D. Modified Perthes test
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 A and B

The patient presents with dull aching pain in both legs, along with a history of prolonged standing and tortuous veins, which are typical symptoms of varicose veins or saphenofemoral incompetence (a condition where the valves in the saphenous vein, particularly at the saphenofemoral junction, are not functioning properly). To diagnose this, certain physical tests are used to assess venous insufficiency.

Here’s a breakdown of the relevant tests:

  1. A. Brodie Trendelenburg Test: This test is used to assess saphenofemoral valve competence. The patient is asked to lie down with the legs elevated, and then they are asked to stand while the veins are observed. If the veins fill rapidly as the patient stands, it suggests incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve.

  2. B. Morrissey’s Test: This is another test used to evaluate venous insufficiency, particularly in the case of saphenofemoral incompetence. It involves applying a tourniquet to the thigh and assessing whether the veins empty, indicating valve function.

  3. C. Fegan’s Test: This test is used to assess for deep vein insufficiency, not specifically for saphenofemoral incompetence. It is not typically part of the diagnostic evaluation for saphenofemoral valve dysfunction.

  4. D. Modified Perthes Test: This test is used to assess deep venous insufficiency and is not specifically focused on the saphenofemoral junction. It involves checking the veins for reflux after the patient is placed in various positions.

questions.text: Recent increase in NCD is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Secular trends

Secular trends refer to long-term changes or patterns in a population's health or disease occurrence over a period of time, typically years or decades. These trends can indicate shifts in health behaviors, environmental exposures, or the impact of public health interventions. The recent increase in non-communicable diseases (NCDs), such as heart disease, diabetes, and cancer, is an example of a secular trend because these changes occur gradually over a long period of time.

questions.text: A new drug launched in the market reduces mortality but doesn’t cure the disease. The drug will?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Correct Answer: A. Increase prevalence

Explanation:
Prevalence refers to the total number of cases (both new and existing) of a disease in a population at a given time. If a drug reduces mortality but does not cure the disease, it means patients live longer with the disease. As a result, more people remain in the population with the condition over time, thereby increasing the prevalence. This is a common epidemiological effect seen in chronic diseases that become more manageable with effective treatment—patients don’t die from the disease as quickly but continue to be counted as existing cases.

questions.text:
Arrange in Sequence

I. Randomization

II. Blinding

III. Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria

IV. Statistical analysis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

III > I > II > IV

  1. III. Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria: Before starting the study, the researchers define the criteria for selecting participants. These criteria ensure that the study population is appropriate for answering the research question and minimizes confounding factors.

  2. I. Randomization: Once the participants are identified, they are randomly assigned to different groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to reduce bias and ensure comparability between groups.

  3. II. Blinding: After randomization, blinding (either single or double) is implemented to prevent bias in the assessment of outcomes. This ensures that neither the participants nor the investigators know which group the participants are assigned to, reducing potential biases.

  4. IV. Statistical analysis: After collecting the data, statistical analysis is performed to interpret the results, compare the groups, and draw conclusions about the efficacy or safety of the intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diagnostic studies - CONSORT

The CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) guideline is not meant for diagnostic studies but is specifically designed for randomized controlled trials (RCTs). It provides a standard for reporting the methodology and findings of RCTs to ensure transparency and reduce bias.

  • A. Systematic review - PRISMA: This is correct. PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) provides guidelines for reporting systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

  • C. Observational studies - MOOSE: This is correct. MOOSE (Meta-analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology) is a set of guidelines for reporting meta-analyses of observational studies.

  • D. Case report - CARE: This is correct. CARE (Case Report) guidelines are designed for reporting case reports, ensuring the documentation is thorough and follows a structured format.

questions.text: In a village there are screening of family members of patient with hypertension and diabetes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Selective.

In the scenario described, where family members of a patient with hypertension and diabetes are being screened, this is an example of selective screening.

Selective screening involves targeting a specific group of individuals who are at a higher risk for a particular condition, based on factors such as family history, age, or other risk factors. In this case, screening is focused on family members, who are at an increased risk of developing these conditions due to their genetic predisposition.

questions.text: HEADSS assessment is done for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adolescent.

The HEADSS assessment is a psychosocial screening tool used to assess adolescents. It focuses on evaluating various aspects of a teenager's life that can impact their health and well-being. The acronym HEADSS stands for:

  • H: Home environment

  • E: Education and employment

  • A: Activities

  • D: Drugs and alcohol use

  • S: Sexuality

  • S: Suicide and depression

questions.text: Anaemia Mukt Bharat: not a part of strategy is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

6 health functionaries.

Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) is a national initiative launched by the Government of India aimed at eliminating anemia, particularly among women and children, through a comprehensive approach. It involves a set of strategies designed to reduce anemia prevalence in the country.

The AMB strategy consists of:

  1. 6 Interventions: These interventions are designed to address the root causes of anemia, including iron and folic acid supplementation, deworming, and addressing dietary deficiencies.

  2. 6 Beneficiary Groups: The initiative focuses on key populations most affected by anemia, including pregnant women, lactating mothers, children, and adolescent girls.

  3. 6 Institutional Mechanisms: These mechanisms are put in place to ensure the delivery of interventions and tracking of progress, including health systems, education systems, and community-based platforms.

questions.text: Pus swab cotton discarded in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Yellow

In healthcare settings, medical waste, including pus swabs and other contaminated materials, should be discarded according to proper color-coded waste segregation protocols. The yellow bin is typically used for infectious waste, which includes materials contaminated with bodily fluids, such as pus swabs, dressings, and other items that have come into contact with infectious substances.

questions.text: Immediate life-threatening injuries is classified in which colour of triage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Red.

In triage systems, which are used to prioritize treatment during emergencies, such as mass casualty incidents, the injuries are categorized by severity to ensure that those who need immediate medical attention receive it first.

  • Red: Represents immediate life-threatening injuries that require urgent attention. These patients are in critical condition and need immediate treatment to survive, such as those with severe bleeding, airway obstruction, or cardiac arrest.

  • Yellow: Refers to serious injuries that are not immediately life-threatening but still require medical attention. These patients can wait for a short period without immediate danger to life.

  • Green: Represents minor injuries that are not life-threatening, and these patients can wait for longer periods for treatment (often referred to as "walking wounded").

  • Black: Refers to patients who are deceased or have injuries so severe that they are unlikely to survive, even with treatment.

questions.text: Two doctors were asked to report 100 X- rays and Kappa value 0.71; what is interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
The Kappa statistic (Cohen’s Kappa) is a measure of inter-rater agreement for categorical items, correcting for the agreement that could happen by chance. A Kappa value of 0.71 indicates substantial agreement, which is generally considered good.

The widely accepted interpretation of Kappa values is:

  • < 0.00 = Poor agreement

  • 0.00 – 0.20 = Slight agreement

  • 0.21 – 0.40 = Fair agreement

  • 0.41 – 0.60 = Moderate agreement

  • 0.61 – 0.80 = Substantial agreement (Good)

  • 0.81 – 1.00 = Almost perfect agreement (Very good)

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about this standard distribution?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

choices.text: Arithmetic mean is affected by extreme values.
Mode is most affected by extreme values.
Median is calculated by overall observation.
Mode can be used as qualitative data descriptor.

questions.text: All the following statement are true for central tendency except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:

  • Arithmetic mean is highly affected by extreme values (outliers). 

  • Median is the middle value and is not much affected by extremes, but it is based on the overall order of observations. 

  • Mode is the most frequently occurring value and can be used to describe qualitative or categorical data (e.g., blood groups, marital status). 

  • Mode is not affected by extreme values since it depends only on frequency, not magnitude. Hence, saying “Mode is most affected by extreme values” is false.

questions.text: In Kaplan Meier survival curve, bands used for confidence interval is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hall-Wellner band.

In the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, the confidence interval (CI) for the survival estimate at each time point is typically represented by bands. The Hall-Wellner band is a method used to create these confidence intervals around the Kaplan-Meier survival estimates.

  • The Hall-Wellner band is widely used to construct the confidence intervals of the Kaplan-Meier survival estimate. It is known for being an effective and accurate method for approximating the confidence intervals.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disorder of possession of thought?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thought echo (Option A) is not a disorder of possession of thought. Thought echo refers to the experience where an individual hears their own thoughts as if they are being repeated aloud, but it is not considered a disorder of thought possession. It is more related to auditory hallucinations, which can occur in conditions like schizophrenia or certain mood disorders, but it does not fall under the category of disorders that specifically involve the control or possession of thoughts.

questions.text: Which of the following domains in MMSE testing has been given highest score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), Orientation (Option A) is given the highest score. The MMSE is a widely used screening tool for assessing cognitive function. The Orientation domain assesses the individual’s awareness of time and place, which includes questions such as the current date, day of the week, month, and year, as well as their location (e.g., hospital, city). This domain is assigned 10 points, which is the highest of any domain in the MMSE.

questions.text: Drug of choice for schizophrenic patient with poor oral absorption can be all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clozapine (Option C) is not the drug of choice for a schizophrenic patient with poor oral absorption. Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is usually administered orally, and it is highly dependent on good gastrointestinal absorption. In cases where a patient has poor oral absorption, clozapine may not be effective because it requires reliable absorption from the gastrointestinal tract to reach therapeutic levels. Additionally, clozapine is associated with a higher risk of side effects, including agranulocytosis, requiring regular blood monitoring.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of atypical antipsychotics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The primary mechanism of action of atypical antipsychotics (Option D) is 5HT2A antagonism. Atypical antipsychotics, including clozapine, olanzapine, risperidone, and others, primarily act by blocking the 5HT2A receptors in the brain. This antagonism is believed to contribute to the effectiveness of these drugs in managing schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. The blockade of 5HT2A receptors helps modulate the effects of serotonin, which plays a critical role in mood regulation and psychosis. This action is also thought to contribute to the lower incidence of side effects, such as extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), compared to typical antipsychotics.

questions.text: Which of the following nutrients, if deficient, can make treatment of depression difficult?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Folate (Option D) deficiency can make the treatment of depression difficult. Folate, or vitamin B9, plays a crucial role in the production of neurotransmitters like serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine, which are involved in regulating mood. Low levels of folate have been linked to treatment-resistant depression. In fact, studies have shown that folate supplementation can enhance the effectiveness of antidepressant medications. When folate is deficient, it can impair neurotransmitter synthesis and hinder the body’s ability to respond well to antidepressant treatments, making depression more challenging to manage.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents to her psychiatrist in hopes that she can find help in dealing with the sexual abuse that occurred in her childhood. While retelling her story of the numerous encounters the patient had with her abuser, the psychiatrist begins to feel protective and parental towards the client, wishing that he could have somehow helped the young girl. Which of the following best describes the feelings that the psychiatrist has for the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Countertransference refers to the emotional reactions and projections that a therapist unconsciously experiences toward a patient, often based on the therapist’s own past experiences, emotions, or unresolved conflicts. In this case, the psychiatrist begins to feel protective and parental toward the 14-year-old patient who has been sexually abused. These feelings suggest that the psychiatrist is emotionally identifying with the patient in a way that goes beyond professional empathy, which may stem from the psychiatrist's own psychological background or personal experiences. This is a classic example of countertransference, and being aware of it is crucial in therapy to maintain objective and ethical boundaries.

questions.text: Which of the following is a clinical advantage of using a second-generation SAD over a first-generation device during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Ability to provide gastric decompression

The primary clinical advantage of second-generation supraglottic airway devices (SADs) over first-generation devices is their ability to provide gastric decompression. Second-generation SADs, such as the LMA ProSeal or i-gel, are designed with a separate gastric drain channel that allows for the passage of an orogastric tube. This feature helps to vent gastric contents, reduces the risk of gastric insufflation, and offers a degree of protection against aspiration. This makes them safer in scenarios where gastric insufflation is a concern, such as during positive pressure ventilation. The ability to decompress the stomach is especially useful in longer procedures or in patients at higher risk of regurgitation, making this feature a significant clinical advancement.

choices.text: Chest compressions should be performed at a depth of at least 3 cm in adults
You should check for a pulse every 5 seconds during compressions
Allow full chest recoil between compressions without leaning
Delay compressions until the AED arrives

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding high-quality CPR for a BLS provider?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: High-quality CPR includes allowing complete chest recoil to enhance venous return. Depth should be at least 5 cm in adults, pulse checks are done every 2 minutes, and compressions should be started without delay.

choices.text: It is ineffective against benzylisoquinolinium muscle relaxants like atracurium
It causes cholinergic side effects like bradycardia and bronchorrhea
It requires co-administration of anticholinergics to prevent side effects

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains a limitation of sugammadex in routine clinical use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 

It is ineffective against benzylisoquinolinium muscle relaxants like atracurium

Sugammadex is a selective binding agent specifically designed to reverse the effects of aminosteroid non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, such as rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating these drugs, rendering them inactive and allowing for rapid recovery of neuromuscular function. However, benzylisoquinolinium compounds like atracurium and cisatracurium have a different molecular structure and are not effectively bound by sugammadex. Instead, these agents undergo spontaneous degradation (Hofmann elimination) and do not require specific reversal with sugammadex. This limits the clinical use of sugammadex to scenarios involving aminosteroid neuromuscular blockers, and not the entire class of non-depolarizing agents.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for scorpion sting is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Scorpion venom causes massive release of catecholamines → leads to autonomic storm, hypertension, tachycardia, myocardial dysfunction, and pulmonary edema.

  • Prazosin, an α-1 adrenergic blocker, is the drug of choice as it counteracts vasoconstriction, reduces preload and afterload, improves myocardial function, and reduces mortality.

  • Antisnake venom (ASV) is used for snake bites, not scorpion sting.

  • Furosemide may worsen hypotension and shock in this condition.

  • Telmisartan (an ARB) is not indicated.

choices.text: Basiocciput fuses with the basisphenoid at 18 yrs
Xiphoid process fuses with the body of sternum at 40 yrs
Medial end of clavicle appears at 18-19 yrs
Upper end of tibia appears at 1 yr

questions.text: Which amongst the following is not the correct statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation:

  • Basiocciput–basisphenoid fusion: occurs at about 18–20 years 

  • Xiphoid process fusion with body of sternum: happens around 40 years 

  • Medial end of clavicle:

    • Secondary ossification center appears at 18–19 years (puberty age).

    • Fusion completes late, around 20–25 years, making it a key forensic marker for age estimation.

  • Upper end of tibia (proximal epiphysis):

    • Ossification center actually appears at birth (not at 1 year).

    • Fuses around 20 years.

    • Hence, the statement “appears at 1 year” is incorrect
