questions.text: Instrument assisted delivery is not indicated in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cephalo pelvic disproportion

Instrument-assisted delivery is not indicated in the case of cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) because the fundamental issue in CPD is a mechanical mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis. This disproportion prevents the fetus from descending through the birth canal, making vaginal delivery unsafe or impossible. In such situations, using instruments like forceps or vacuum extractors is not only ineffective but may also cause trauma to the mother or baby. Therefore, cesarean section is the preferred and safest mode of delivery when CPD is diagnosed. Instrumental delivery is only safe when vaginal delivery is possible and the presenting part is low enough in the birth canal — which is not the case in CPD.

choices.text: Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck
Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion
Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head
External rotation after delivery of shoulder

questions.text: In restitution:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck

Restitution refers to a specific movement that occurs during the mechanism of normal labor, particularly after the delivery of the fetal head. Once the head is delivered, it appears to rotate slightly to realign itself with the shoulders that are still inside the birth canal. This movement is passive, meaning it is not an active movement by the fetus, but rather a mechanical consequence of the untwisting of the fetal neck. During internal rotation, the fetal head rotates to align with the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvis, creating a twist in the neck relative to the shoulders. After the head is delivered, this torsion is released, and the head rotates slightly (usually about 45 degrees) to realign with the shoulders — this is known as restitution. It helps indicate the position of the fetal shoulders and prepares for the next stage of delivery.

questions.text: In a hypertensive patient presenting with PPH which drug is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Methylergometrine

Methylergometrine (also known as methylergonovine) is contraindicated in hypertensive patients presenting with postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) because it can cause significant vasoconstriction, leading to a further rise in blood pressure. It acts on alpha-adrenergic and serotonin receptors in the smooth muscle of the uterus, promoting strong and sustained uterine contractions to control bleeding. However, its potent vasopressor effects can precipitate or worsen hypertensive crises, stroke, or myocardial infarction in patients with pre-existing hypertension or preeclampsia. Therefore, despite its efficacy in controlling uterine atony, it is not safe for use in hypertensive patients.

questions.text: A patient comes at 30 weeks with decreased fetal movements, per abdomen uterus is 34 weeks and FHR absent her BP is 166/110 mmhg she had wet undergarments but bleeding ahs stopped now. She is 6 cm dilated (50% effaced. What is management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Antihypertensives and ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes)

This patient presents with features suggestive of intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) along with severe preeclampsia (BP: 166/110 mmHg), decreased fetal movements, fundal height greater than gestational age, and no fetal heart rate detected. She is already in active labor (6 cm dilated, 50% effaced), and her wet undergarments with a history of bleeding suggest possible antepartum hemorrhage (e.g., concealed abruption). The goal in this situation is to expedite vaginal delivery, since the fetus has demised and cesarean section is not indicated in IUFD unless there are compelling maternal indications. Therefore, ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes) is appropriate to augment labor and hasten delivery. Antihypertensives are essential to control the severe hypertension and prevent complications like eclampsia or stroke.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not given in endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Estradiol

Estradiol is not used in the treatment of endometriosis because it is a form of estrogen, the hormone that actually stimulates the growth of endometrial tissue. Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent condition where endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus, leading to pain, inflammation, and sometimes infertility. Administering estradiol would worsen symptoms by promoting the proliferation of ectopic endometrial tissue. Treatment of endometriosis typically involves reducing estrogen levels or counteracting its effects to suppress ectopic tissue growth and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Choose the incorrectly matched option
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cystocele- Colposuspension

Colposuspension (such as Burch colposuspension) is a surgical procedure used primarily to treat stress urinary incontinence, not cystocele. While cystocele (anterior vaginal wall prolapse due to bladder descent) may sometimes coexist with incontinence, the standard treatment for cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy, which repairs the anterior vaginal wall and repositions the bladder. Therefore, pairing cystocele with colposuspension is incorrect, making this the right choice for the question

questions.text:
On investing for infertility the mal partner was found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism: How
many of the following are associated with this condition?
A. Azoospermia/severe oligospermia
B. Low LH, low FSH
C. Low LH, high FSH
D. Low testosterone
E. Low prolactin level
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A, B and D

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition characterized by a deficiency in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion from the hypothalamus or a failure of the pituitary to release LH (luteinizing hormone) and FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone). As a result, there is insufficient stimulation of the testes, leading to low testosterone production and impaired spermatogenesis. This results in azoospermia (absence of sperm) or severe oligospermia (very low sperm count) due to inadequate FSH stimulation of Sertoli cells and LH stimulation of Leydig cells. Low LH and low FSH levels are hallmark features of this condition because the problem originates at the hypothalamic or pituitary level. Additionally, testosterone levels are low due to reduced stimulation of the Leydig cells by LH.

questions.text: High risk hpv does not cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngeal papilomatosis

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV types, particularly HPV 6 and 11, which are known for causing benign lesions such as genital warts and respiratory papillomas. These types are not associated with malignant transformation. While the condition can cause significant morbidity due to airway obstruction or voice changes, it is not linked to high-risk HPV types (like HPV 16 and 18), which are oncogenic and associated with several anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers. Hence, laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk HPV.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Menorrhagia with normal cycle length and regularity suggests Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding (DUB), most often due to ovulatory causes (endometrial dysfunction).

  • First-line management is always medical (non-surgical) unless contraindicated.

Step-wise management of menorrhagia:

  1. Non-hormonal therapy (already tried in this patient):

    • Tranexamic acid (antifibrinolytic).

    • NSAIDs (e.g., mefenamic acid).

  2. Hormonal therapy (next step):

    • Combined oral contraceptives (COCs).

    • Cyclical progestins.

    • Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS).

    • These regulate endometrial proliferation and reduce blood loss. 

  3. Endometrial ablation / Uterine artery embolisation:

    • Considered when patient is older, has completed childbearing, and medical therapy fails.

  4. Hysterectomy:

    • Definitive treatment, but reserved for refractory cases or associated pathology.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with 2 years of primary infertility. Her cycles are regular and she has no history of dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia. She underwent an HSG which showed bilateral tubal patency. Her husband’s semen analysis is normal. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a normal uteruswith an antral follicle count (AFC) of 5. Day 3 labs show:
• FSH: 14 IU/L
• LH: 5 IU/L
• AMH: 0.6 ng/mL
What is the most likely cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Poor ovarian reserve

This 32-year-old woman presents with primary infertility and normal menstrual cycles, and investigations have ruled out common causes like tubal factor infertility (normal HSG) and male factor infertility (normal semen analysis). However, her ovarian reserve markers are significantly impaired: she has a high FSH (14 IU/L), low AMH (0.6 ng/mL), and a low antral follicle count (AFC of 5). These findings are strongly indicative of poor ovarian reserve, which means her ovaries have a reduced quantity and potentially quality of oocytes. Despite her regular menses, diminished ovarian reserve can still impair fertility and response to stimulation in assisted reproductive techniques, making it the most likely cause of her infertility.

choices.text: Dual trigger with hCG and GnRH agonist
Coasting until estradiol levels fall, followed by hCG trigger
GnRH agonist trigger in antagonist cycles with frozen embryo transfer
Immediate oocyte retrieval when follicles reach 10 mm

questions.text: A woman undergoes infertility treatment and her Usg shows follicles bigger than 18 mm and serum E2 level is 3500 pg/ml Which of the following reduces the risk of OHSS without compromising pregnancy rates in high-risk women?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

GnRH agonist trigger in antagonist cycles with frozen embryo transfer
This approach allows oocyte retrieval while avoiding the risk of OHSS progression due to pregnancy.

The GnRH agonist trigger reduces luteinization and VEGF expression, and a freeze-all strategy  eliminates endogenous hCG exposure from early pregnancy — both critical in preventing late OHSS.

Option B, although practiced in some cases, still involves hCG exposure, which may still precipitate OHSS if not timed precisely — thus not the most effective strategy compared to Option C.

questions.text: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What Is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stage II B

Cervical carcinoma staging is based on the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) system, which classifies the disease according to the extent of tumor spread. In this case, the tumor is described as a 6 cm lesion extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. According to the FIGO staging system:

  • Stage II involves the spread of the tumor beyond the cervix but not to the pelvic wall or lower third of the vagina.
    • Stage II A refers to tumor involvement of the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement.
    • Stage II B refers to tumor spread to the parametria (as in this case), with or without vaginal involvement.

Since this tumor has spread to the parametrium, it fits the criteria for Stage II B cervical cancer.

questions.text: During your time in the labor room, you performed a vaginal examination on a primigravida female. The exam showed that the anterior cervix had a soft consistency, was dilated to 3 cm, and measured 3 cm in length. In this case, you would assign a Bishop score of 1 to which of these cervical characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Station -2
The Bishop Score is used to assess cervical favorability for labor induction. It includes five
components, each scored 0–3:
Dilatation = 3 cm → Score: 2
Soft consistency → Score: 2
Anterior position → Score: 2
Station = –2→ Score: 1 ← This is the one that gets a score of 1.

choices.text: Start oral labetalol and monitor as outpatient
Administer magnesium sulfate and prepare for delivery

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G2P1, at 34 weeks’ gestation presents with headaches and blurred vision. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. There is no history of hypertension prior to pregnancy. She has 2+ lower extremity edema. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Administer magnesium sulfate and prepare for delivery

This patient is presenting with classic signs of severe preeclampsia, a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy. Key features include elevated blood pressure (160/100 mmHg), significant proteinuria (3+), and symptoms such as headaches and blurred vision, which suggest impending end-organ damage. The presence of edema further supports this diagnosis. In severe preeclampsia, the risk of seizures (eclampsia) increases, which is why magnesium sulfate should be administered to prevent seizures. The most appropriate next step is to prepare for delivery, as the only definitive cure for preeclampsia is delivery of the placenta. Given the severity of her condition and her gestational age of 34 weeks, immediate delivery may be necessary, and careful monitoring for complications should be started.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is unable to conceive for 1 year. Semen analysis of her partner shows azoospermia. FSH is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Sertoli-cell-only syndrome

• 1 year of infertility
• Semen analysis shows azoospermia (no sperm in ejaculate)
• FSH is elevated - indicates testicular failure
• It’s a non-obstructive cause of azoospermia
• Seminiferous tubules contain only Sertoli cells, with no germ cells
• This leads to:
o Azoospermia
o Elevated FSH (due to lack of inhibin B from Sertoli cells loss of negative feedback)
• Leydig cells often function normally testosterone levels may be normal

questions.text:
27-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, spotting, and 6 weeks of amenorrhea. She is hemodynamically stable.
Which of the following support the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy?

1. Empty uterus on TVS

2. Visualization of adnexal mass on TVS

3. Presence of free fluid in pouch of Douglas

4. Presence of fetal cardiac activity in uterus

ANSWER USING THE CODE GUVE. BELOW
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1, 2, 3
• 27-year-old woman
• Lower abdominal pain, spotting, 6 weeks of amenorrhea

• Hemodynamically stable
These features are classic for ectopic pregnancy. Now let’s evaluate the options:
Statements supporting ectopic pregnancy:
1. Empty uterus on transvaginal sonography (TVS)
Suggests no intrauterine pregnancy, which is suspicious in a woman with positive pregnancy test and
6 weeks of amenorrhea.
2. Visualization of adnexal mass on TVS
Highly suggestive of an ectopic gestation, especially if a gestational sac or "ring of fire" sign is seen.
3. Presence of free fluid in pouch of Douglas
Suggests possible rupture or leakage from an ectopic site — concerning for ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gestational age of 32 weeks

Vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery (VAVD) can be a helpful tool in certain labor situations, but it has specific contraindications due to the risk of complications, especially in preterm infants.

Gestational age of 32 weeks is a contraindication:

• Preterm infants (<34–36 weeks) have fragile skulls and immature brains, which significantly

increases the risk of:

o Intraventricular hemorrhage

o Scalp injuries

o Cephalohematoma

questions.text: Which of these is not a test of Down syndrome done in first trimester?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:

  • First trimester (11–13+6 weeks) screening for Down syndrome includes:

    1. Combined test → Nuchal translucency (NT) + serum markers (PAPP-A ↓, free β-hCG ↑). 

    2. Nuchal translucency (NT) alone → ultrasound marker. 

    3. NIPT (Non-invasive prenatal testing / cell-free fetal DNA in maternal blood) → can be done from 10 weeks. 

  • Second trimester screening (15–20 weeks):

    • Triple test (AFP, β-hCG, unconjugated estriol). 

    • Sometimes extended to quadruple test (adds inhibin A).

choices.text: Visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) every 5 years
High-risk HPV DNA testing every 5–10 years

questions.text: According to WHO 2021 guidelines, which of the following is recommended as the preferred method for primary cervical cancer screening in women aged 30–49 years?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

High-risk HPV DNA testing every 5–10 years
The World Health Organization (WHO) 2021 guidelines recommend:
High-performance HPV DNA testing as the preferred primary screening method for women aged
30–49 years, with screening intervals of 5–10 years if results are negative.
• Preferred and recommended by WHO 2021.
• Higher sensitivity for detecting cervical precancer.
• Allows for longer intervals between screenings.
• Because it's the most sensitive and preferred method for primary cervical cancer screening in the
target age group according to WHO 2021 guidelines.

choices.text: Spermatogenesis is completed in the epididymis
Acrosome is derived from the Golgi apparatus
Mitochondrial sheath is located in the head of the sperm
Spermiogenesis involves mitotic division of spermatogonia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spermatogenesis and sperm maturation is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:

  • Option A: Spermatogenesis is completed in the epididymis 

    • Spermatogenesis occurs entirely within the seminiferous tubules of testes.

    • In the epididymis, sperm undergo maturation (gain motility, fertilizing ability), not spermatogenesis.

  • Option B: Acrosome is derived from the Golgi apparatus 

    • The acrosome (enzyme-containing cap that helps sperm penetrate the ovum) is formed from Golgi vesicles during spermiogenesis.

  • Option C: Mitochondrial sheath is located in the head of the sperm

    • Mitochondria are arranged spirally around the midpiece, not in the head.

  • Option D: Spermiogenesis involves mitotic division of spermatogonia

    • Spermiogenesis is the final stage of spermatogenesis, involving transformation of spermatids → spermatozoa (no cell division, only morphological changes).

    • Mitotic division of spermatogonia occurs at the beginning of spermatogenesis, not during spermiogenesis.

questions.text:
Parameters for failure to respond in SAM, incorrect?

A. Failure to lose edema by day 4

B. Edema on day 10

C. Failure to gain weight 5g/kg/d by day 20

D. Weight/height reach -2SD

E. Appetite not increased by day 4
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

C,D

In the context of Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), certain parameters indicate a failure to respond to treatment. These parameters help clinicians identify when the treatment is not achieving the expected improvements in the patient's condition.

  • C. Failure to gain weight 5g/kg/d by day 20: A failure to gain 5 grams per kilogram per day of body weight by day 20 is an important indicator of treatment failure in SAM. This parameter helps assess the effectiveness of the nutritional intervention. If the child is not gaining weight at the expected rate, it suggests that the treatment regimen may not be adequate or there might be underlying complications affecting recovery.

  • D. Weight/height reach -2SD: This refers to a failure to achieve a weight-for-height ratio above -2 standard deviations (SD), which indicates that the child has not recovered enough to be classified as moderately malnourished or above. If the weight-for-height remains below this threshold, it suggests that there has been insufficient progress in addressing the malnutrition.

choices.text: Kasai’s surgery should be done before 3 months
Most common cause of neonatal cholestasis
HIDA used for diagnosis in all
Liver biopsy can help in differentiating from others

questions.text: What is incorrect in EHBA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIDA used for diagnosis in all

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is a rare but serious condition where there is a blockage or absence of the bile ducts outside the liver, leading to cholestasis and liver damage. The statement about HIDA scan (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan) being used in all cases of EHBA is incorrect. While HIDA scans are an important diagnostic tool, they are not always used in every case. The diagnosis of EHBA is often confirmed by clinical presentation, imaging studies (like ultrasound), and surgical exploration. A HIDA scan is typically used when there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or when other imaging methods do not provide conclusive results.

questions.text: INSURE used in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RDS

INSURE stands for INtubation-SURfactant-Extubation, which is a technique primarily used in the management of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in neonates, particularly premature infants. This procedure involves the following steps:

  1. Intubation – the baby is intubated to provide mechanical ventilation.

  2. Surfactant administration – a dose of surfactant is given to help improve lung compliance and reduce surface tension in the alveoli, which is crucial in managing RDS, a condition where the lungs are not fully developed, leading to difficulty in breathing.

  3. Extubation – the baby is extubated, often after a short period, to support spontaneous breathing.

This method is used to provide immediate support for neonates with RDS while promoting the baby's own ability to breathe after surfactant administration.

questions.text: Head circumference increase in the first 3 months of life [per month]
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The head circumference in infants increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first 3 months of life. This rapid growth reflects the brain's rapid development during this period. After the first three months, the rate of increase slows down but continues throughout the first year of life, with the head circumference reaching about 45 cm by the age of 12 months in typical development.

questions.text: What is NOT seen in nutritional rickets?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Urine calcium creatinine ratio > 15

In nutritional rickets, the primary cause is a deficiency in vitamin D, leading to impaired calcium and phosphorus metabolism and affecting bone mineralization. The common findings include:

  • A. Normal calcium: In early stages of nutritional rickets, calcium levels may be normal because the body can compensate by mobilizing calcium from the bones. However, in more severe cases, calcium levels can be low.

  • B. Low phosphorus: Low levels of phosphorus are typically observed in nutritional rickets, as phosphorus metabolism is often impaired due to vitamin D deficiency, which decreases the renal reabsorption of phosphate.

  • D. High PTH: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is often elevated in nutritional rickets. As calcium levels drop or are mobilized from bones, the body compensates by increasing PTH secretion to increase calcium reabsorption from the kidneys and promote calcium release from bones.

questions.text: Not seen in Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Purulent conjunctivitis

Kawasaki disease is an acute systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children. It involves inflammation of the blood vessels and can lead to serious complications, especially in the coronary arteries. The typical features of Kawasaki disease include:

  • B. Strawberry tongue: The strawberry tongue is a classic finding in Kawasaki disease. It is characterized by a red, swollen tongue with enlarged papillae, giving it a "strawberry" appearance. This is a sign of mucosal involvement, which is one of the diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

  • C. Polymorphic rash: A polymorphic rash is another common feature of Kawasaki disease. The rash can take various forms, including maculopapular, urticarial, or erythematous, and is often seen in the acute phase of the illness. It typically affects the trunk and limbs.

  • D. Cervical Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) is one of the key clinical signs of Kawasaki disease. The lymphadenopathy is often unilateral and can be quite large, sometimes reaching over 1.5 cm in diameter.

choices.text: Cl- increased in sweat and pancreatic secretion
Cl- decreased in sweat and pancreatic secretion
Cl- decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic secretion
Cl- increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic secretion

questions.text: In Cystic Fibrosis, which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cl- increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic secretion

In Cystic Fibrosis (CF), the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein, which regulates the transport of chloride (Cl-) and other ions across cell membranes, is defective. This results in various symptoms and complications, particularly related to the respiratory, digestive, and sweat glands.

  • Sweat: In CF, chloride (Cl-) concentration is increased in sweat because the CFTR protein is defective, leading to poor reabsorption of chloride in the sweat ducts. This is why one of the diagnostic tests for CF is the sweat chloride test, where high levels of chloride in sweat indicate the disease.

  • Pancreatic secretion: In the pancreas, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride secretion into the pancreatic ducts, which impairs the normal flow of digestive enzymes. This contributes to pancreatic insufficiency, which is common in CF patients. As a result, there is a lack of proper digestion and nutrient absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following is best indicator of severe HIE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypotonia

In Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE), a condition caused by a lack of oxygen and blood flow to the brain during or shortly after birth, hypotonia (low muscle tone) is one of the most significant clinical indicators of severe HIE. Hypotonia typically reflects severe central nervous system (CNS) damage, indicating that the brain has been significantly affected by the hypoxic-ischemic event. The presence of severe hypotonia is associated with a poor prognosis and the need for intensive management and monitoring.

questions.text: Most common pattern of Pott’s spine involvement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The most common pattern of involvement in Pott’s spine (tuberculous spondylitis) is paradiscal. Tuberculosis of the spine primarily affects the area near the intervertebral disc (paradiscal region). The infection typically begins in the vertebral body and spreads to the adjacent disc. As a result, the vertebral body collapses, leading to deformities such as kyphosis (hunchback) and sometimes spinal instability. This paradiscal involvement is characteristic of the slow, progressive nature of the infection, which can involve multiple vertebrae over time and is often seen in individuals with a weakened immune system or untreated tuberculosis.

choices.text: Injury to anterior inferior glenoid labrum
Depression in posteroinferior head of humerus
Depression in the posterosuperior part of head of humerus

questions.text: True statement about Bankarts lesion in recurrent anterior dislocation of shoulder:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Injury to anterior inferior glenoid labrum

A Bankart lesion refers to an injury to the anterior inferior glenoid labrum, typically resulting from recurrent anterior shoulder dislocations. During these dislocations, the head of the humerus moves out of the glenoid cavity, and when it returns, it can cause tearing of the labrum in the anterior-inferior part of the glenoid. This injury weakens the shoulder joint, making it more susceptible to future dislocations.

choices.text: Kuch Bhi ho / It doesn't matter

questions.text: Osteoporotic fracture is usually seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vertebra

Osteoporotic fractures most commonly occur in the vertebrae (Option A). Osteoporosis weakens the bones, making them more susceptible to fractures, especially in areas where the bone density is naturally lower, such as the spine. Vertebral fractures often result from minimal trauma, such as bending or lifting, and they are typically seen in older individuals, especially postmenopausal women. Compression fractures in the vertebrae are a hallmark of osteoporotic bone damage.

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs, when he was made bear weight on right lower limb the left sided pelvis dropped down but when he was standing on left lower limb the right sided pelvis moved up. Lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

The symptoms described—difficulty walking upstairs and pelvic instability when bearing weight on the right leg and left leg—are indicative of a right superior gluteal nerve palsy (Option A). The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus, which are responsible for stabilizing the pelvis during walking, especially when standing on one leg. A lesion of the right superior gluteal nerve causes weakness in the right gluteus medius and minimus, resulting in an inability to maintain pelvic stability. When the patient bears weight on the right lower limb, the left pelvis drops (positive Trendelenburg sign), and when standing on the left leg, the right pelvis rises, which confirms the right-sided nerve lesion.

questions.text: 24 year old female with Right Proximal one third fracture of shaft of femur. What will be the best suited treatment ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intramedullary Nails/ Interlocking Nails

For a right proximal one-third fracture of the shaft of the femur, intramedullary nails or interlocking nails (Option A) are the best-suited treatment. This is because these methods provide strong, stable fixation for femoral fractures, especially in the shaft and proximal regions. Intramedullary nailing is the preferred treatment for diaphyseal femoral fractures as it allows for early mobilization, better alignment, and quicker recovery, which is crucial for a 24-year-old patient. It is minimally invasive, reduces the risk of complications like nonunion, and offers good fracture healing.

questions.text: A PATIENTWITH STAB INJURY TO CHEST. SUPINE XRAY GIVEN. DIAGNOSIS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Right hemothorax

In the context of a stab injury to the chest, a supine chest X-ray may reveal homogeneous opacification of the right hemithorax, blunting of the costophrenic angle, or a layering effect of fluid, which are all suggestive of a hemothorax. In the supine position, blood does not layer dependently as it does in upright films. Instead, it spreads posteriorly and can obscure lung markings or cause a diffuse hazy appearance. This is particularly important in trauma patients who cannot be positioned upright. A right-sided stab wound raises the suspicion of injury to the intercostal vessels, lung parenchyma, or great vessels, resulting in accumulation of blood in the pleural space (hemothorax). Therefore, based on the mechanism of injury and radiological findings in a supine film, right hemothorax is the most likely diagnosis

questions.text: WHICH NORMAL ANATOMIC VARIANTIS SEEN IN THIS CT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

An aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA) is a common vascular anatomical variant, where the right subclavian artery arises abnormally from the distal part of the aortic arch (usually as the last branch) and passes posterior to the esophagus to reach the right upper limb. On a CT scan, especially on axial views, this can be seen as a vascular structure posterior to the esophagus, sometimes causing mild compression or indentation. This condition is often asymptomatic, but in some cases, it may cause dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression. Recognition of ARSA is important in surgical and endovascular planning, especially during procedures involving the aortic arch. In this CT, the appearance of a vessel coursing posterior to the esophagus without signs of inflammation or mass effect supports the diagnosis of aberrant right subclavian artery,

questions.text: IDENTIFY THE MARKED LIGAMENT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) is one of the two cruciate ligaments located in the center of the knee joint. On imaging, particularly sagittal MRI views, the PCL is visualized as a thick, strong band coursing posteriorly from the tibia to the medial femoral condyle, running obliquely upwards and forwards. It is typically larger and more vertical than the ACL. In this case, the marked ligament follows the typical orientation and location of the PCL, situated posterior to the ACL, and appears as a dense, well-defined structure extending from the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia to the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle. Its anatomical position and appearance confirm that the correct identification is the PCL.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic lower back pain. MRI of the lower back shows the following findings. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Spondylolisthesis

Spinal metastasis is a common cause of chronic back pain in elderly individuals, particularly in patients over 50 years of age. On MRI, metastatic lesions typically appear as hypointense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2-weighted images, with possible contrast enhancement. They often involve the vertebral body, and may show destruction or replacement of normal bone marrow with irregular margins. The MRI might also reveal epidural soft tissue mass or spinal cord compression depending on the extent. In this 56-year-old woman with chronic back pain and characteristic imaging findings, spinal metastasis is the most likely diagnosis, especially if there is vertebral collapse, multiple lytic or sclerotic lesions, or heterogeneous marrow signal on MRI. This diagnosis is critical to identify early due to the potential for neurologic compromise and the need for systemic cancer workup.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man has been experiencing worsening headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI with contrast was done and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glioblastoma

Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most aggressive and common primary malignant brain tumor in older adults, especially in those over 60 years of age. The patient’s worsening headaches and new-onset seizures are typical presenting symptoms due to increased intracranial pressure and cortical irritation. On MRI with contrast, glioblastomas typically appear as irregular, ring-enhancing lesions with central necrosis, surrounding vasogenic edema, and mass effect. They frequently cross the corpus callosum, producing the classic "butterfly" pattern. The enhancement pattern, age of the patient, and rapid neurological progression are characteristic of glioblastoma, making it the most likely diagnosis in this clinical context.

questions.text: Inhaled nitric oxide useful in-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO):

    • Potent pulmonary vasodilator.

    • Acts by stimulating guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → smooth muscle relaxation.

    • Causes selective pulmonary vasodilation without systemic hypotension (because it is rapidly inactivated by hemoglobin once absorbed into blood).

    • Used in pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH), persistent pulmonary hypertension of newborn (PPHN), and acute right heart failure due to pulmonary vasoconstriction. 

  • Other options:

    • Unstable angina / NSTEMI: treated with nitrates, antiplatelets, anticoagulants, but not inhaled nitric oxide. 

    • Erectile dysfunction: treated with sildenafil (PDE-5 inhibitor), not inhaled NO directly.

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs modulate voltage gated sodium channel and enhances slow inactivation of sodium channel?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • Voltage-gated sodium channel (VGSC) modulation is a key mechanism for many antiepileptics.

  • Phenytoin & Lamotrigine: act mainly by stabilizing the fast inactivation state of sodium channels. 

  • Topiramate: has multiple mechanisms (sodium channel blockade, GABA enhancement, AMPA/kainate receptor inhibition), but not specifically slow inactivation. 

  • Lacosamide: unique because it enhances the slow inactivation of sodium channels without affecting fast inactivation. This stabilizes hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive firing.

questions.text: Cannabidiol is not given in –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:

  • Cannabidiol (CBD) is an FDA-approved antiepileptic drug (brand name: Epidiolex).

  • Approved indications:

    1. Dravet syndrome 

    2. Lennox–Gastaut syndrome 

    3. Tuberous sclerosis complex–associated seizures 

  • Rett syndrome: Though it is a neurodevelopmental disorder associated with seizures, cannabidiol is not approved / not given specifically for this condition.

questions.text: Drugs useful In DM neuropathy post herpatic neuralgia & spinal cord injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

EXPLANATION:

A. Pregabaline

Diabetic neuropathy
Post-herpetic neuralgia
Neuropathic pain due to spinal cord injury

B. Carbamazepine
trigeminal neuralgia, Neuropathic pain (off-label), Can be useful in spinal cord injury–related pain

C. Amitriptyline

Diabetic neuropathy,Post-herpetic neuralgia also helps with central pain syndromes

D.  Galantamine

Alzheimer’s disease

questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING HORMONE WITH THEIR RECEPTOR
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

  • Insulin → Tyrosine Kinase (2):
    Insulin binds to its receptor, which is a receptor tyrosine kinase. Upon insulin binding, the receptor undergoes autophosphorylation on tyrosine residues and triggers downstream signaling pathways like the PI3K-Akt pathway and the MAPK pathway. This mechanism is characteristic of tyrosine kinase-linked receptors.

  • Growth Hormone → JAK-STAT (4):
    Growth hormone does not have intrinsic kinase activity. Instead, it binds to a cytokine receptor which activates the JAK-STAT pathway. After GH binding, Janus Kinases (JAK) are activated, which phosphorylate STAT proteins that move into the nucleus to influence gene expression.

  • Acetylcholine (Ach) → Ligand-gated receptor (1):
    At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine binds to nicotinic receptors, which are ligand-gated ion channels. Binding of Ach opens the channel, allowing sodium influx and causing depolarization of the muscle membrane leading to contraction.

  • Thyroxine → Nuclear receptor (3):
    Thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) act through nuclear receptors. After entering the cell, they bind to receptors in the nucleus, regulating gene transcription directly. This mechanism is slow but long-lasting, typical for steroid and thyroid hormones.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used in thyroid storm except?-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aspirin

  • Aspirin is contraindicated in thyroid storm.
    Although aspirin is an antipyretic, it is not used in thyroid storm because it can displace thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) from their protein-binding sites in the blood. This displacement increases the free, active thyroid hormone levels, worsening the thyrotoxicosis. Therefore, aspirin can actually exacerbate the symptoms of a thyroid storm rather than control them, making it inappropriate for use in this critical condition.

questions.text: Which anti-diabetic drug is recently approved for treatment of heart failure with low ejection fraction along with impaired renal function?-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Empagliflozin is a SGLT-2 inhibitor that was initially approved for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, recent studies (like EMPEROR-Reduced trial) have shown that empagliflozin significantly improves outcomes in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), even in patients without diabetes.

  • It has cardioprotective and renoprotective effects: it reduces hospitalization for heart failure, improves cardiovascular mortality, and also slows the progression of renal dysfunction.

  • Therefore, empagliflozin is now approved for use in heart failure with low ejection fraction, including patients with impaired renal function

choices.text: Rifampicin: Inhibits DNA dependent RNA polymerase
Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibit protein synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the mechanism of action of antimicrobial drugs?-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibit protein synthesis

  • Linezolid actually binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit, not the 30S, and inhibits the initiation of protein synthesis by preventing the formation of the initiation complex.

  • It is primarily effective against Gram-positive bacteria, including resistant strains like MRSA and VRE.

  • Therefore, the statement "Linezolid binds to 30S ribosome" is false, making Option B the correct choice for this question.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs useful in leprosy causing skin pigmentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Clofazimine

  • Clofazimine is an anti-leprosy drug that is well known for causing skin pigmentation as a side effect.

  • It deposits in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, leading to a characteristic reddish-brown to black discoloration of the skin, which is often more pronounced in sun-exposed areas.

  • This pigmentation is dose-dependent and reversible over time after discontinuation, but it can persist for months.

  • Clofazimine's main action is bactericidal against Mycobacterium leprae by binding to mycobacterial DNA and interfering with bacterial growth.

questions.text: LIVER FLUKE DOC-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Triclabendazole

  • Triclabendazole is the drug of choice (DOC) for liver fluke infections, especially for Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica.

  • It works by disrupting microtubule function in the parasite, impairing motility and essential metabolic processes, ultimately leading to parasite death.

  • It is highly effective against both the mature and immature stages of liver flukes, which makes it superior to other antihelminthic agents in this specific condition.

  • Due to its targeted action and favorable safety profile, WHO recommends Triclabendazole as first-line therapy for liver fluke infestations.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is the PARP inhibitor useful in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rucaparib

  • Rucaparib is a PARP (Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase) inhibitor, primarily used in the treatment of BRCA-mutated cancers, including breast and ovarian cancer.

  • PARP is an enzyme involved in single-strand DNA break repair. In BRCA1/BRCA2-mutated cancer cells, which already have defective homologous recombination repair, inhibition of PARP leads to accumulation of DNA damage and cell death — a concept known as synthetic lethality.

  • Rucaparib, along with other PARP inhibitors like olaparib and talazoparib, has shown significant efficacy in triple-negative and BRCA-mutated breast cancer, making it a valuable targeted therapy option.

questions.text: All of the following drugs targeting against HER-1 receptor EXCEPT-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pertuzumab

  • Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER-2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2), not HER-1.

  • It works by binding to the dimerization domain of HER-2, preventing its interaction with other HER family receptors, particularly HER-3. This blocks downstream signaling pathways that promote cell growth and survival in HER-2 positive cancers like breast cancer.

  • Since the question is asking for the exception (i.e., the drug not targeting HER-1), Pertuzumab is the correct answer.
